dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full face of Lee, wearing a gray sweater and leaning against the dining room doorway.  She gazes into the came with a half-smile on her face as Elliot speaks over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, she's beautiful. Lee glances over her shoulder, then turns from the doorwa and walks away.  The camera follows her, moving across a book-and-photograph-filled bookshelf that obscures her fr view as she walks into a crowded, comfortable vestibule. People, some holding drinks, some just entering the apartment, surround her.  Everyone is talking at once, carrying on easy, familiar conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got the prettiest eyes, and she looks so sexy in that sweater. Lee smiles at the various people, exchanging greetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, how are you? Two more guests enter the apartment; the vestibule is ful now.  Still walking, Lee lightly hugs one of the children she continues on her way towards the living room.  Elliot voice, as well as the jazzy music, is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to be alone with her and hold her and kiss her... Lee walks into the living room, turning her head back for moment to talk to the child she has just hugged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and tell her how much I love her and take care of her.  Stop it, you idiot.  She's your wife's sister. But I can't help it. The camera is still moving with Lee as she smiles and sto to chat with her mother.  Elliot's voice, as well as the music, continues over the low din of warm conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm consumed by her.  It's been months now.  I dream about her.  I- I, I think about her at the office. Oh, Lee. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do? Lee starts to walk off again, finishing her conversation with her mother.  She passes several other guests, then turns to greet April, giving her a warm, brief hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear myself mooning over you, and it's disgusting.  Before, when she... Elliot's voice-over continues as he is actually seen, standing in a doorway having a conversation with a gestur rotund man.  Both are holding drinks as Lee, carrying a t of hors d'oeuvres and two drinks, walks between them.  Th space is very tight; the men hold up their drinks to make room for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...squeezed past me in the doorway, and I smelled that perfume on the back of her neck... Elliot watches Lee walk off; the other man, oblivious, continues to talk.  Elliot reluctantly returns to the conversation, but he can't help turning his head to gaze the offscreen Lee as the other man chatters on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Jesus, I, I thought I was gonna swoon!  Easy... The camera resumes following a smiling Lee.  She has just put down the tray and drinks near April, and briskly and obliviously, she walks past a doorway where Elliot, still ruminating, watches her, entranced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dignified financial advisor.  It doesn't look good for you to swoon. The camera stays with Elliot, who is still watching the offscreen Lee.  In the background, guests continue to chatter warmly with each other. Hannah, carrying a tray of hors d'oeuvres, walks up behin the distracted Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart? Elliot returns from his reveries with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you tried these?  These are wonderful. (nibbling, swallowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly and her friend made them. Elliot, taking one of the hors d'oeuvres, starts nibbling well as he and Hannah walk past the bookshelf into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister is an unbelievable cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know!  I know! Elliot and Hannah, eating and talking, walk past a hallwa and offscreen as Holly appears, walking down the hallway. She holds a drink and a plate of hors d'oeuvres; she stan at the entrance to the hallway, eating and looking at the offscreen guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has all the cooking talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she doesn't, either.  You've got tons as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh, but I've eaten five of these. Holly, standing in the hallway onscreen, swallows loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly, why don't you open your own restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to the offscreen Elliot and Hannah, trying to swallow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, we practically are.  Well... (holding her hand to her mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April and I are going to do some catering!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, we decided! Holly takes a sip of her drink as Hannah and Elliot walk over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm...I mean, we love to cook for our friends, so (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we thought until an acting job comes through, we could just make some extra money, you know, doing a few private parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Holly and Hannah begin to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I speak to you privately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. Holly and Hannah walk off; Elliot watches them leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after them as he nibbles on an hors d'oeuvre)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm her husband!  She tells me anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, licking her fingers, walks past a memo-cluttered refrigerator to the stove as Holly, behind her, begins to speak.  The faint sounds of music are still heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, I have to borrow some more money. (sipping her drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stirring some food in a saucepan on the stove)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, I never get upset over that. Mmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last time, I promise. And I'm keeping strict accounts. As Holly talks, sipping her drink, Hannah busily works in the kitchen, which contains a large center table stacked with bowls and plates of food, hanging pots and pans, and general party clutter.  She walks on-and-offscreen as she talks and listens to her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting her empty glass and plate down on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday, I'll pay it all back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  H-how much do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand dollars. Hannah, who'd been mashing some food in a bowl on a nearb counter, hesitates momentarily.  She turns to Holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, I know it's a lot, but my friend April and I, we have this catering idea I think's going to be great. Hannah, licking her fingers, walks past Holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You admit that we're great cooks, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, back at the stove now, stirring in a pot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in order to get started, there's just a few things I have to buy... (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and some old debts I have outstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just tell me one thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we talking about cocaine again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear.  I swear.  We've already got some requests to do a few dinner parties. A timer goes off.  Hannah walks past Holly to attend to s food on a different stove.  Holly turns to face her.  Onl Holly is seen as she talks to the offscreen Hannah, the camera moving in closer on her face.  As Holly speaks, sh distractedly nibbles an hors d'oeuvre.  In the background her parents can be heard singing in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, obviously, I'm not going to be a caterer forever, you know.  We both still go to auditions. Something could turn up at any moment.  But the parties are at night, days are free, I can still take my acting class.  I haven't done drugs on a year. Holly pops another hors d'oeuvre into her mouth as the background singing gets louder and the film cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is crowded with family and guests sitting comfortably on chairs near the piano, where Evan, Hannah' father, plays "Bewitched" as Hannah's mother, Norma, sits nearby, accompanying him in their duet.  A child is spraw out under a blanket on a sofa; some guests chatter quietl others drink and eat, listening. EVAN & NORMA (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A whimpering, simpering Child again Bewitched, bothered, and bewildered Am I..." As they continue to sing, the film cuts back to the kitch where Lee, carrying some glasses, enters through the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad are floating down memory lane again! Lee walks over to her sisters, putting the glasses down o counter.  Hannah is scooping seeds out of a cantaloupe. Holly, leaning on the table, sips her drink.  The music f the living room is softly heard as the three sisters chat comfortably and easily with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah... Hey, have you tried Holly and her friend's shrimp puffs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need an antihistamine.  Mom thinks she's feeling her asthma, and so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Mom's Camille when she gets up in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least she isn't drinking.  Did you notice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to look at her sisters, laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't she look great in that new dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The sisters all talk at once; Hannah is still working at sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she knows it, too, 'cause she's flirting with all the men here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe when she's eighty, she'll stop straightening her garter belt when there's a guy around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get a garter belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a garter belt... (sipping her drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a garter belt and flirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don-- Ask Elliot for that. Uh, he's got them somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Lee leaves the kitchen.  Holly, puffing on her cigarette, watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Holly, still working at the sink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does Frederick ever come with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch.  He's such an angry...he's such a depressive.  I thought she was moving out! Hannah shakes her head in disapproval while Holly angrily takes another sip of her drink. And the film cuts briefly back to the living room, where Evan is still playing the piano and singing.  The camera moves past him and a few guests to Norma, who is enthusiastically singing along, looking at Evan and movin her hands. EVAN & NORMA (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A pill he is But still he is All mine and I'll Keep him until he is Bewitched, a'both--"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is beautifully set for Thanksgiving dinner, complete with candles, flowers, cut crystal, china, and silver.  Hannah's children are playing in the room as Han enters, carrying a huge roast turkey.  Behind her is Holl carrying a casserole.  Hannah's parents can still be hear singing in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, your kids are so adorable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting down her bowl on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it gets so lonely on the holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting down the turkey on the opposite end of the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, gosh.  Well, you know, that's why I invited Phil Gammage tonight. As the sisters talk, the piano music stops.  There's the sound of light applause as Evan begins a new song, faintl heard in the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a loser at all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping, lighting a set of candles on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the headmaster of Daisy's school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, perfect!  He reminds me of Ichabod Crane. (moving her hand up and down her throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Adam's apple keeps jumping up and down whenever he gets excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.  He's a lot better than your ex-husband.  He's got a good job. (handing a pack of matches to Holly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you light those, please? He's-he's-he's not a dope addict or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (striking a match to light another set of candles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I interrupting... The film cuts to April, standing in the doorway of the dining room and holding a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. The camera moves with April as she walks over to the tabl where Hannah and Holly are lighting candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...because there are no interesting single men at this party!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe April would like Phil.  Phil Gammage, the tall guy in there by the piano. Holly groans, looking at her sister, while April sips her drink and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm-mm.  Oh, yeah.  I met Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the--He looks like Ichabod Crane? Hannah screams with laughter as she walks toward the end the table, past a gleeful Holly, who points her finger at Hannah as she passes.  Hannah, still laughing, playfully pushes the accusing finger away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that.  That's my type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it! She walks over to a nearby china cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, I really like him a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, we mustn't get discouraged. As Holly continues to tease her sister, Hannah opens a drawer in the cabinet.  She takes out two apples decorate with paper turkey heads and tails and hands them to April

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah will invite some men over who don't look like Ichabod Crane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. April starts to put the turkey apples on the table.  A bemused Hannah takes two more out of the cabinet and plac one of them on the table as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping, to April, who has just set down her apples)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe at Christmas, New Year's.  If not this New Year's, maybe next New Year's. While Holly is talking, Hannah hands her the last turkey apple, accidentally sticking her with one of the toothpic that keeps the decorations in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! The film cuts to a short hallway leading to a bathroom in Hannah's apartment.  In the foreground is a standing lamp In the background, Elliot is seen walking inside the bathroom, looking around the room.  Light piano music is dimly heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be here someplace. He walks out of the bathroom, moving down the hallway towards the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know, I, I love that book you lent me.  The Easter Parade? You were right.  It had very special meaning for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Frederick?  He didn't come. Elliot walks into the bedroom as Lee continues to talk offscreen.  The camera, leaving Elliot, moves across the room, past a wall of framed paintings, a headboard and be a night table and lamp, revealing Lee. She is flipping through a book by a curtained window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, you know Frederick.  One of his moods.  Although it wasn't a bad week.  He (onscreen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great. The camera stays with Lee as she walks around the room, p another curtained window, a television set, and a rolltop desk.  She absently flips through the book as she talks t the offscreen Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was, it was one of his better drawings, a very beautiful nude study.  Actually, it was of me. (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny, you know, it's a funny feeling to know you're being hung naked in some stranger's living room. Lee puts the book she's been holding down on the desk, on to pick up another one.  She looks at the offscreen Ellio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can't tell it's me, although-- (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're turning all red, Elliot. She reacts.  The camera moves to a blushing Elliot, follo him now as he walks across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  So, so, what else?  Wh- what are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know.  My unemployment checks are running out.  Um, I was thinking of taking some courses at Columbia with the last of my savings. As Lee speaks, Elliot parts a hanging curtain against the wall to reveal a stereo and some records.  He looks at th offscreen Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly. As Elliot reaches inside the stereo shelf, grabbing a bot of antihistamines, the camera moves back to Lee, who sits down on the bed.  She is still holding a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sociology, psychology maybe.  I always thought I might like to work with children. Elliot walks over to Lee; he sits down on a footstool in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing with the bottle of pills gripped in his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incidentally, I-I always have clients who are furnishing places. Some of them might-might be interested in buying art.  Shall I, shall I call you? (chuckling self-consciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. (taking the bottle of pills Elliot hands her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, uh, Frederick would really by grateful for a sale. She chuckles; Elliot smiles and chuckles with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you guys? Elliot turns in the direction of his wife's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner's ready. Hannah, eating a carrot stick, enters the bedroom.  The camera stays with her momentarily as she walks towards Elliot and Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...ex-husband on the street the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was, he's just as crazy as ever. He was on his way to get a blood test. (laughing, Elliot joining in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Mickey's such a hypochondriac. I wonder how he'd handle it if there was ever anything really wrong with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go have dinner, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is seated around the table for Thanksgiving dinn Facing the camera are Holly, Lee, Norma, and Hannah.  She sits to the left of Elliot, who's at the head of the tabl On his right is Evan; April sits next to him.  She and th other guests sit with their backs to the screen.  The tab overflows with food, floral decorations, and candles.  In the background, the children sit at a separate table; a m serves them turkey.  The guests chatter comfortably among themselves as they eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clanking a piece of silverware against his water glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. Evan continues to clank his glass to get everyone's atten

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starving! Resigned, Holly puts down her silverware.  Lee smothers a laugh.  Norma, reacting, glances at Holly and Lee.  Every knows what's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...this is a toast!  This is a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching across the table for Evan's wine glass, laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a toast.  You know this beautiful Thanksgiving dinner was all... Holly laughs.  Lee glances over to her, reacting.  Hannah embarrassed, reacts and sits with her hands on her face. Lee and the rest of the guests put down their silverware. They look at Evan, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...prepared...by Hannah. Hannah, embarrassed, makes a victory sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, and a little help... Lee and Holly try to suppress their laughter.  Norma glar at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...from Mavis, also. Elliot wraps his arm around Hannah; he pulls her towards affectionately and kisses her on the cheek.  She hugs him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping, looking down the table while still in Elliot's embrace)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly and April, thanks for helping. Mavis the maid exits, carrying some trays, as the group starts to cheer and applaud.  Holly waves her napkin at April, then holds up her wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am... I did slave all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we drink to her, and we all congratulate her on her wonderful accomplishment during this last year...her great success in A Doll's House! The group continues to cheer as they all toast Hannah.  S reacts, smiling but embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I played Nora.  I hate to tell you what year... The guests, sipping their wine, quiet down as Norma conti to speak.  Lee and Holly unsuccessfully try to contain th laughter.  Mavis reenters the dining room to serve more f to the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's very difficult to behave like Torvald's little chipmunk without making a perfect ass out of yourself! (pausing while the guests laugh heartily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I think that Ibsen would have been damn proud of our Hannah! Norma toasts her daughter; everyone follows her.  The applause and cheers begin anew.  Hannah, reacting, chuckl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea-a-a-a-ah! A few guests sip their wine.  They all quiet down as Hann starts her speech, glancing around the table and gesturin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that.  Oh, no, I just, see, I-I've been very, very lucky.  W-when I had the kids, I decided to stop working and just, you know, devote myself to having the family, and I've been very, very happy (banging her fists lightly on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: but...I've always secretly hoped that maybe some little gem would come along and tempt me back on the stage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just for a second.  So, now I got that out of my system and I can go back to the thing that makes me happiest. Hannah tenderly takes Elliot's hand as she looks around t table.  He, in turn, kneads her shoulder, chuckling with equal tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, bravo!  Bravo! Hannah, still embarrassed, looks down at a plate.  The gr applauds once more, toasting and drinking, and warmly sounding their approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We all had a terrific time." Classical string music plays as the film cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi moves down Broadway towards the camera, passing a truck on the right, the Winter Garden marquee advertising Cats, and several buildings, and as the taxi moves offscr the classical music still playing, the movie cuts to the taxi's backseat.  Lee sits by the window, leaning her hea in her hand, a reflective look on her face.  Her voice is heard over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it my imagination, or does Elliot have a little crush on me? (chuckling slightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny.  I've had that thought before.  He pays a lot of attention to me all the time, and he blushed tonight when we were alone in the bedroom.  I wonder if he and Hannah are happy?  It's funny, I...I still feel a little buzz from his flirting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee stirs a cup of coffee on the counter of the loft's modern kitchen area; a nearby vase hold flowers.  She wal across the loft, with its high ceilings and beige walls, holding her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. Lee continues to walk, past a modern chaise, a bookcase, some sofas, two columns.  Lamps hang down from the ceilin The classical music still plays in the background.  Lee stops at a plastic-enclosed work area.  Frederick can be seen working at a drawing board on the other side of the clear plastic screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing. The background music stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, what am I gonna do with you? (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lee walks over to the drawing board where Frederick is sitting, he is seen intently cleaning some paintbrushes w a rag.  Lee stands by him, leaning over the board, and lo directly at him.  The table is filled with cans of brushe and artist's equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why didn't you come tonight? We all had a terrific time.  I really think you would have enjoyed yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going through a period of my life where I just can't be around people. (putting down the brushes and wiping his hands with the same rag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to wind up abusing anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to abuse them. They're all so sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you are the only person I can be with...who I really look forward to being with. (pulling Lee to him, around the board)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too harsh with everyone. You know that, don't you? Frederick and Lee embrace; Lee sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it enough that I can love you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sweet with me and so...contemptuous of everyone else. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there was a time (sniffing again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: when you were very happy to be only with me.  You wanted to learn everything about poetry, about music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I really taught you everything I have to give? (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Lee kisses Frederick twice, then releases him and walks o of the work area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Elliot said he might have a couple of clients for you. Lee walks over to the loft's stereo area, pulling up the sleeves of her sweater as Frederick talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure all those morons he handles have a deep feeling for art. Lee picks up a book from the stereo shelf.  She leans bac against the unit, glancing through its pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you never know.  They might.  He's just trying to do the nice thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Frederick, leaving his work area, walks past Lee; his han are in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Lee as he goes by)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Based on what?  You never even see him. The camera stays with Frederick as he walks into the loft bedroom area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Based on...whenever you see him, you always come home full of books he's recommended... He sits down at the foot of the bed and starts taking off his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, no.  He's my sister's husband.  And I think if you gave him half a chance, you'd like him. He's very intelligent. Lee sits down next to Frederick; he takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a glorified accountant, and he's after you. (kissing Lee's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I prefer to sell my work to people who appreciate it, not to rock stars. (kissing Lee's face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand? Lee kisses Frederick back on the cheek.  They embrace. Frederick laughs; their embrace gets tighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upbeat jazz plays in the background and continues as the film cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal elevator doors open and Mickey Sachs, a high-powere television producer, walks out, deep in conversation with his assistants, Paul and Larry.  As the elevator operator begins to reclose the door with his passengers, Mickey, h assistants fast behind, walks down an office corridor pas busy groups of studio personnel.  Indistinct conversation as well as the jazz, is heard in the background as the tr talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, they won't let us do the sketch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to Standards and Practices. They think it's too dirty. The trio pass Mary, another assistant, in conversation wi two other co-workers.  She holds a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we showed it to them in rehearsal! Without missing a beat, he takes Mary's wrist and continu walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, what'd they do, figure out what the words mean? A foursome now, they briskly walk past a man and a woman going over a script.  Mary and Mickey lead; Paul and Larr follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey, we got a half hour to air! As the group walks through a large doorway, Larry catches to Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're short!  The show is five minutes short! The group turns right into a new corridor, briefly off th screen.  As they scurry off, their voices are heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could it be short?  We timed everything (offscreen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we have to... They are all now seen walking down the new corridor towar the camera.  The corridor is crowded with busy TV personn The group continues to talk frantically as people hurry p them.  One man pushes rudely past Mary as he walks; she looks back at him briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...pull out the sketch, then we'll be ten minutes short!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how they can do that to us.  That's-- We go on in thirty minutes, right? Mary checks her wristwatch as they rush down the corridor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're doing it because our ratings are low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got such a migraine. As the group briskly walks past an open door, Gail, anoth assistant, runs out, brandishing her glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Mickey! Gail runs in front of the group.  Without missing a step, she faces Mickey and walks backwards, gesturing and talki frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey!  Listen, we better go right to Ronny's dressing room.  This kid must have taken sixteen hundred Quaaludes.  I don't think he's going to be able to do the show! The fast-tracking group turns the corner.  Gail pats Mick back; she gestures in exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me, Lord?  What did I-- He is interrupted by Ed Smythe, an official from the Standards and Practices Department, who's been standing i the corridor waiting for Mickey.  Mickey stops and shakes Ed's hand as if he'd known the official would be there. Gail stops by his side while the others walk into a background studio doorway that is busy with scurrying personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Why, all of a sudden, is the sketch dirty? (putting his hands on his hips)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Child molestation is a touchy subject...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read the papers!  Half the country's doing it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We nev-- We don't name names! (turning to Gail for support, briefly touching her shoulders, then looking back at Ed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...cannot go on the air. A writer, holding a script, walks out of the background studio, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Mickey, Gail, and Ed turn towards the writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who changed my sketch about the PLO? Mickey and Gail walk over to the angry writer, Ed forgott with this new crisis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to make some cuts.  It's four lousy lines!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole premise is ruined! Mickey, Gail, and the writer start walking down a corrido adjacent to the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, trying to calm the writer down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're crazy!  It's not so delicate.  Everybody's married to every line. The writer reacts angrily.  Gail tries to get Mickey's attention as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care!  I don't want anyone tampering with my goddamn work without telling me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want 'em cut?!  I'll cut 'em myself! Mickey, still in surprised shock, turns away from the ang writer.  He stands by an open dressing room, where Ron, a actor, slouches, dazed, in a chair facing a makeup mirror People mill in the background behind the actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping, trying to get Mickey's attention and gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distractedly, his mind still on the writer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... (muttering as the writer passes him and walks away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In-in-in-instead of the child molestation sketch, why don't we repeat the Cardinal Spellman Ronald Reagan homosexual dance number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel good, Mickey. Mickey, remembering Ron, runs into the dressing room.  Ga follows him.  Inside, a man and a woman talk, ignoring Ro They share a drink in a paper cup.  The woman looks back Ron; she gestures with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, wh-- Yeah, what did you do? Swallow a drugstore?! Ron coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my voice. Gail walks around the chair.  The camera shows she and Mickey talking to Ron through the reflection in the clutt makeup mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron...Ronny, you know you do have to go on in twenty-five minutes. Ron sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, does anybody got a Tagamet? My, my ulcer's starting to kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a Quaalude? Mickey, as reflected in the mirror, starts to pace as the movie cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, a Los Angeles TV producer and Mickey's former partner, is driving down a peaceful street lined with pal trees.  He's wearing sunglasses and headphones.  He click his fingers in time to the music only he hears on his Walkman.  He's smiling contentedly while Mickey talks ove the sun-filled scene.  The continuous background jazz pla louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, this show is ruining my health!  Meanwhile, my ex-partner moves to California and every stupid show he produces turns out to be a big hit.  Brother, what am I gonna do with my life?  Speaking of that, I-I...gotta remember to see my ex-wife tomorrow.  Tch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mickey finishes his ruminations, Hannah is seen walkin towards her front door.  She opens it, her back to the camera.  Mickey stands there holding two boxed gifts.  Th jazz stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad you could put in an appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. Hannah nods as Mickey comes inside.  She closes the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got two minutes. 'Cause, God, the show is killing me.  I got a million appointments today.  It just so happens it fell this way. Hannah continues to nod patiently, patting Mickey on the back, as they make their way across the foyer into the de where the twins are playing.  Mickey wears his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta see new comedians later, I've gotta--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes on your sons' birthday. You know, it's not going to kill you. Her voice trails off as Mickey walks over to the twins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, fellas!  Happy Birthday! Hannah's twins greet Mickey with cries of "Hi, Daddy!" an indistinct chatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping their chatter, bending down to talk to her sons)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, look what Daddy brought. Presents! Mickey hands a gift to each twin.  They grow quiet, sudde shy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, aren't you like, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a little, uh, hey!  A little hug! What is this?  Now how 'bout a little action from the kids? The twins put down their gifts, one on the sofa, one on t coffee table, and hug their father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up the gift on the sofa and nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, kids, you can open the presents now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, you guys.  Open them up. Hannah makes room on the coffee table for the gift she is holding; she places it next to the other one.  The boys start opening them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get a little reaction here. (to Hannah, putting his hands in his pockets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know what?  I'm trying to convince him to produce a play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he'll find that satisfying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  That'll be terrific for him, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like him.  I think he's a sweet guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The few times that I've met him... (pointing to the baseball mitt twin #1, has taken out of his box)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H-he's so awkward and he's clumsy like me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so I, so I like that.  I always like an underconfident person...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, he's been wanting a mitt. She helps Twin #2 open his present.  It's a football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've always had good taste in husbands, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning down to look at the football)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Football! Twin #2, panting, runs offscreen to catch the football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on!  Hurry up!  Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still pointing, gearing up for the pass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go out, go out by the Sung vase and, and catch this. Mickey throws the football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, d-- Watch, watch the picture. There's a sound of breaking glass.  Hannah and Mickey rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey is walking up a West Side street, his hands in his coat pockets.  Jazz plays in the background as he talks o the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Hannah's sweet.  Although, sometimes I still do get angry when I think of things.  Oh, what the hell.  At least, I'm not paying child support. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I hope there's nothing physically wrong with me, either. Mickey pushes open the outside door of Dr. Abel's office, the movie cuts to the doctor's consultation room.  The doctor is framed in the doorway, looking through a file cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the, uh, problem this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time I really think I have something. While Mickey answers him offscreen, Dr. Abel turns and wa toward him.  The camera follows the doctor's movements fr the other side of the wall, obscuring him briefly. It moves across a dark examining-room wall to a second doorway, where Mickey sits on a stool, continuing to talk the offscreen Dr. Abel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I'm absolutely convinced that-that-- You know, I mean, it's not like that adenoidal thing, you know, where I didn't realize I had them out. Dr. Abel walks back onscreen.  Both he and Mickey are now seen through the second doorway.  Dr. Abel sniffs and sta directly in front of the sitting Mickey.  He stares down him as Mickey talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, so, but it was when I was younger, so--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I saw your father this week about his sinus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and, uh, he complained of chest pains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this guy's the real hypochondriac of the family.  I mean, he's, you know, he's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mentioned on the phone that you'd had some dizziness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, a little dizziness, and I think, I think I'm developing a hearing loss in my right ear (poking at his ears and gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...or my left ear, my, my left...oh, n-n-n-no.  No, I'm sorry.  It was my right, my right, my right or my left ear. Dr. Abel chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a look. An uptempo big-band sound is heard as the movie cuts to Mickey's examination, beginning with a close-up of Dr. Ab using an otoscope to examine the ear of a nervous Mickey. Next is a hearing test.  The film shows the doctors's han turning the dials on a sonometer.  Mickey sits on a nearb high stool, large earphones on his head.  He listens with such concentration that he squints his eyes.  He holds up finger in response to the sounds he hears in his headset. Finally, the film shows Dr. Abel hitting a large turning fork with his finger.  He puts the vibrating fork to Mick ear.  Mickey, looking up at the offscreen doctor's face, The music stops as the film cuts back to Dr. Abel's consultation room.  Dr. Abel walks from the examining roo through the consultation room, to a second examining room across the way.  He talks to the offscreen Mickey as he w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry to say you have had a significant drop in the high- decibel range of your right ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?! Dr. Abel moves offscreen in the second examining room.  T camera stays focused on the doorway to this room as the doctor and Mickey talk offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been exposed to a loud noise recently, or did you have a virus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I-I've been perfectly healthy. You know me. Dr. Abel briefly passes by the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always, I-I always imagine that I have things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you first notice this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, about a month ago.  Wha- what do I have? Looking preoccupied, Dr. Abel walks back into the consultation room, holding Mickey's open file.  He stride over to his desk, revealing a frightened Mickey, sitting a chair opposite it.  Still standing, the doctor leans ov the desk, his back to the camera, and makes a few notes i the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about ringing and buzzing? Have you, uh, noticed any of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, now-now that you mention it, uh, I-I-I have, uh, buzzing and also ringing.  Ringing and buzzing. Um, am I going deaf, or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's just in one ear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, is it, is it, uh, healthier to have problems in both ears? Dr. Abel chuckles as he closes Mickey's file and straight up.  The camera looks past his back and shoulders to the anxious Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'd like to do, is to make an appointment for you at the hospital. I'd like to have them run some tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hospital?  What kind of tests? Dr. Abel lays his pen across Mickey's closed file.  He wa around his desk and sits on its edge close to Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, don't get alarmed.  These are just more sophisticated audiometry tests than I can run here. (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it's nothing, then why do I have to go into the hospital at all?  I mean, uh, I hear perfectly fine, so I'm, so I'm a little weak on the, on the high decibels.  So I, you know, I won't go to the opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there's no reason for panic.  I just want to rule out some things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing.  Will you trust me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey stands in a telephone booth on a corner near Dr. Abel's office; he talks on the phone.  It is raining.  A and a woman holding an umbrella pass by; traffic moves across a nearby intersection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh, uh, hello, Dr. Wilkes?  Dr. Wilkes, this is Mickey Sachs.  You have a minute?  I want to ask you a question. The film cuts to Dr. Wilkes, on the telephone at his end. He is in his office; he leans back in his chair, dangling his stethoscope as he speaks.  Behind him, a chest X-ray mounted on a light panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mickey.  What's up? The movie cuts back and forth between Mickey in his phone booth asking questions and Dr. Wilkes in his office answe them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-if you have, i-if you have a hearing loss in one ear, and-and it's not from a, uh, virus or a loud noise or anything, wh-what are the possibilities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.  Uh, often it's hereditary. Flu, uh, even a small noise will do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I guess the, uh, dark side of the spectrum is a brain tumor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the telephone, reacting with a blank stare)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail, wearing her glasses, stands behind a crowded but we ordered desk.  Two assistants, a man and a woman, stand around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing them each some pages of script)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so here's the new pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, really.  Really. The assistants walk off.  As they leave, Gail calls out after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, we'll be down in a minute, okay? The telephone starts to ring, Gail pauses, looking offscr She takes off her glasses and squints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey, what's the matter with you? You're all white! The film cuts to Mickey, who is pacing and wringing his hands.  He walks over to Gail.  The phone continues to ri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel dizzy.  Sshh, you know, I don't feel well. He starts to pant, looking worriedly around the room.  He continues to wring his hands as Gail stares at him, conce

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear a ringing?  Is there, is there a, is there a ringing sound? (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Yeah, yeah.  I hear, I hear it. She sits down and picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering first one ear, then the other, continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like-- (putting a finger into his ear, closing his eyes and listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, yeah.  We're going to be working late tonight.  N-no, we'll order out.  It's all right.  Yeah. Gail hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssss, if I have a brain tumor, I don't know what I'm gonna do. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a brain tumor.  He didn't say you had a brain tumor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: they're not gonna tell you, because, well, you know, th--, sometimes the weaker ones will panic if you tell 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God! (looking around worriedly and touching Gail's shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear a buzzing?  Is there a buzzing? He pants and begins to pace around the room.  The camera follows him as he walks away from Gail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey, come on, we got a show to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't keep my mind on the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's nothing wrong with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's nothing wrong with me (pacing back to the desk and Gail)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: then why does he want me to come back for tests?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he has to rule out certain things. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that!  I don't want to hear that word! (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention that while I'm in the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't have any symptoms!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You--I got the classic symptoms of a brain tumor! Mickey sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months ago, you thought you had a malignant melanoma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally, I, I--Do you know I--The sudden appearance of a black spot on my back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I--How was I to know?! (pointing to his back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone was pointing back here. He sighs again as Gail, frustrated, gestures impatiently the papers on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we've got to make some booking decisions. Mickey begins pacing around the room again.  He wrings hi hands and blows on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.  I can't think of it. This morning, I was so happy, you know.  Now I, I don't know what went wrong. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, you were miserable this morning! We got bad reviews, terrible ratings, the sponsors are furious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pacing back to the desk, still wringing his hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was happy, but I just didn't realize I was happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stanislavski Catering Company in action. Sophisticated pop music plays as the film cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abstract painting on a wall fills the screen.  Light laughter is heard, as well as the sophisticated music; offscreen brunch guests chatter indistinctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These things are delicious!  What in the world are they? Holly walks onto the screen in front of the painting.  Sh holds an almost empty tray of hors d'oeuvres; she wears a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, um, those are quail eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they're very good. Holly walks past the painting towards the female brunch guest.  A man walks in front of her.  Chatter, light laughter, and music are still heard; a party is in progre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, my friend April makes those. (holding out the tray)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, try the shrimp puffs.  These are delicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you.  That looks great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm.  Thanks. Holly laughs lightly as she walks away from the woman. Holding her tray, she passes a large oval loft window and several clusters of brunch guests.  They are eating and drinking.  No one pays any attention to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to two male guests in her way)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. One of the men, murmuring his thanks, takes a last shrimp puff as Holly passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Holly finally makes her way into the cluttered loft kitch Her tray is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stroganoff is ready. Holly, excited, runs over to April, who is busy taking th Stroganoff out of the oven.  She wears the same uniform a Holly: black skirt, white shirt, and black bowtie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, in this we're a big hit. Yesterday I auditioned for Come Back Little Sheba.  That, I wasn't such a big hit. April, holding the Stroganoff, dashes out of the kitchen serve the party guests.  Holly calls after her, offscreen as David walks past the hurrying April into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be.  You will be.  You'll get five jobs next week. David walks over to Holly, who is busy at the pot-and-pan covered stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, are there any more claims?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing at some canaps warming on the stove)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a few.  A few. (chuckling as David takes one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  How flattering!  Did you try the shrimp puffs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eating a canap and pointing at Holly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you guys are too attractive to be caterers.  Something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing a quiche from an overhead stove)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  Is the food that bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.  Not at all. As Holly carries the quiche outside to the party, April comes back into the kitchen from another doorway.  Music, well as the chatter of mingling guests, is heard in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need more bread and some baked lasa-- (realizing Holly isn't there and, at the same time, noticing David)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing by the sink as he wipes his hands and mouth with a napkin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  You're an actress with a great flair for shrimp puffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working at the stove, pointing a finger for emphasis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no, the shrimp puffs are Holly's.  I do the, uh, crpes caviar. She walks past David to a counter where she begins to fol napkins.  David leans back against the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the quail is responsible for the quail eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's hope so. Holly enters the kitchen holding out a plate of clams.  S walks over to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, I stole you a couple of extra clams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, April Knox.  Hi. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving the counter and squeezing past David and Holly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. April walks offscreen to another area of the kitchen.  Ho picks up a napkin from the crowded table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, looking at David as she wipes her hands with the napkin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're the Stanislavski Catering Company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm going to tell you the truth. I really came in here because I was bored stiff by the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think we're more interesting? David walks around the table, putting the plate of clams down on the already crowded surface.  Holly follows him, chuckling, throwing her napkin into an offscreen garbage as David stops at a small television set near the doorway Guests in the other room can be seen chatting together in clusters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm going to listen to Aida, if I'm not getting in your way. Canned laughter and miscellaneous chatter is heard from t television set.  David watches the set, still munching on clam, while Holly and April reassure him offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. David checks his wristwatch as Holly walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw, um, Pavarotti, eh, uh, in Ernani at the Met, and I cried...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, his hand still on his watch as he looks at Holly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I-I-I go limp in the last scene in La Traviata.  Limp. Holly chuckles as David, listening to April, impressed, walks over to her.  She is standing by the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.  I have a private box at the Met. (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bring my little bottle of wine, I open it, I sit there and I watch and (glancing over to the offscreen Holly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cry.  It's disgusting. April chuckles as Holly walks back onscreen; she is busy preparing another tray of hors d'oeuvres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what, what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of things do you build?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time do you get off? The three exchange glances.  Holly shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A contemporary red building, designed by David, is seen, squeezed in between two older buildings.  Holly, April, a David talk offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terrific! The film moves down from the buildings to reveal the trio sitting in David's Jaguar across the street.  David and April sit in the front seat; Holly sits scrunched up in back, her head slightly forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, looking back and forth from the buildings to Holly and April)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The design's deliberately noncontextural.  But I wanted to... keep the atmosphere of the street, you know, and the proportions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in the material. That's...that's unpolished red granite. (pausing as he watches Holly and April's reaction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that what it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-i-it has an o-organic quality, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back at the building with reverence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost...almost, uhhh, entirely wholly interdependent, if you know what I mean.  I-I... I can't put it into words.  The important thing is-is-is it-it breathes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, April, people pass by vital structures in this city all the time, and they never take the time to appreciate them.  I get the feeling you tune in to your environment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's really important. David turns and briefly glances at Holly; he then turns b to April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your favorite buildings, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. David starts the car and the movie cuts to an unfolding visual excursion through New York City's landmark buildin as seen from the trio's point of view in the moving Jagua Inspiring classical music plays in the background. The series of shots includes the Dakota, complete with surrounding winter trees, the Graybar building on Lexingt Avenue, an incredibly ornate building on Seventh Avenue a Fifty-eighth Street, a red-stone church, an old building with embellished, bulging windows on West Forty-fourth Street, the Art Deco Chrysler Building, a red-brick build Abigail Adams's old stone house, and the Pomander Walk nestled off Broadway on the Upper West Side.  The group c be seen walking down the path between the old-fashioned r houses and shrubbery.  A lamppost sits in the foreground. It is now dark.  The music continues to play as the film cuts to the faade of a rococo-style building, complete French doors and ornate windows.  The admiring group is heard offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's just so romantic.  I just want to put on a long gown...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and open the French doors and go on the balcony --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's French, though.  It really is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels like you're in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It-it is.  It's romantic. The music stops.  The screen, which has been exploring th rococo building's faade, now shows the equally elegant building alongside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's got a handsome partner sitting right beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fit right in together.  And your eye goes along, lulled into complacency, and then... The film moves from the two elegant faade to show an ug ultra-modern structure covered with tiny, diamond-shaped motifs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does. The film moves from the ugly faade to the building's equally ugly entrance.  A large car is parked right in fr of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...we have seen a lot of stuff today, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of works. The group is now seen walking down the canopied entrance stairs of an apartment house on the other side of the street, where they'd been gazing at both the lovely and u faades across the way.  David is in the lead; the women follow, Holly slightly behind April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should start thinking about going home, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. They walk towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back at the women as he walks around the car to the driver's side)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, gee, I don't know.  Um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I, we both live downtown. David leans over the roof of the car, looking at the wome waiting for their decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on what way you want to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, wait.  You know what?  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If...well, if we took the, if we took Fifth, then-then-then we'd get to your house first, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Yeah, but Fifth is so jammed, isn't it? She looks at David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's jammed.  If we went... um... Both she and April mumble awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-you live in Chelsea, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I-I guess if you live in Chelsea, that's probably first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. They get into the car.  Once again Holly's in the backsea The classical music begins anew. The movie cuts briefly to cut to the traffic and lights o Manhattan avenue as seen from the moving Jaguar.  It then moves to a close-up of Holly, sitting in the backseat, he head near the window.  She is staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally I get taken home first. Well, obviously he prefers April. Of course I was so tongue-tied all night.  I can't believe I said that about the Guggenheim.  My stupid little roller-skating joke.  I should never tell jokes.  Mom can tell 'em and Hannah, but I kill 'em. (glaring at the offscreen April's back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did April come up with that stuff about Adolph Loos and terms like "organic form"? (looking out the side window, pausing for a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, naturally.  She went to Brandeis. The movie cuts to Holly's point of view: the front seat where David and April sit, the Jaguar's windshield, and t passing lights and traffic of the street.  Holly continue her ruminations as April leans over to say something to D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't think she knows what she's talking about.  Could you believe the way she was calling him David? "Yes, David.  I feel that way, too, David.  What a marvelous space, David." (emphatically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate April.  She's pushy. The film moves back to Holly in the backseat, still lost thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they'll dump me and she'll invite him up.  I blew it. (sighing, looking out the side window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I really like him a lot.  Oh, screw it.  I'm not gonna get all upset.  I've got reading to do tonight.  You know, maybe I'll get into bed early.  I'll turn to a movie and take an extra Seconal. The classical music stops and some uptempo jazz begins. screen cuts to black and a title appears. "...nobody, not even the rain, has such small hands."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie briefly holds on a ripped, red, paint-splattere door as Elliot, wearing a raincoat, appears nearby.  He looks down the street and the film cuts to his point of view: Frederick's loft building. The movie goes back to the impatient Elliot; he's looking around him.  He glances at his watch as the film cuts bac once again to the loft building, where Lee finally appear walking down the street away from Elliot.  A truck passes down the street.  Lee doesn't see him.  She walks further and further away; she turns a corner. Elliot frantically looks around again; then, in a burst o decision, he runs around a garbage dump, crossing the street, and still running, he moves down an adjacent stre past The Canal Lumber Company and several other buildings as the film cuts back to Lee, walking down a different street, oblivious. The jazz plays on as the movie cuts back and forth betwee the fast-moving Elliot, rushing down the SoHo streets, pa a truck waiting for a light to change, past some pedestri some garbage cans, turning corners, and the strolling Lee walking up different streets, past different buildings. Lee eventually crosses a street, lost in thought, looking right and left, as Elliot, pretending nonchalance, waits the corner, looking at his watch.  She looks up in surpri the music stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying not to sound out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm-I'm looking for a bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what, in this section of town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I'm killing time.  I have a client near here and I...I'm quite early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes!  You live near here, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I was just going to my AA meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness.  Well, why do you still go to those?  You never tough alcohol. They begin to walk down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, listen, you didn't know me before Frederick.  I'd...I'd start with a beer at about ten in the morning, and...go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  You must have been, uh, very unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I still find the meetings very comforting, you know. She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never understand it.  You're so bright and charming and beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: what problems could she possibly have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let me get started on my childhood. (stopping in her tracks, remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know what?  There is a bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of blocks from here.  If you don't know about it, you should. You'd really love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around for a moment, then gesturing to Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, i-if-if you have some free time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. They begin to walk again as the movie cuts to the interio of the Pageant Book & Print Shop, an old, serious boo A nude print hangs at the end of one of the library shelf like bookcases, which are packed, row after row, with boo An unseen Elliot and Lee carry on a conversation as the camera moves down an aisle, past the rows of books.  A pi playing "Bewitched" is heard.  Pictures hang on the aisle ends of the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What book did you want to buy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your book?  You wanted to buy a book? The camera moves past another aisle of books to reveal Le browsing through a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm killing time.  I...I-I just, uh, w-want to browse, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up at a row of books)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you sure picked the right place.  I mean, you can stay here all afternoon, not buy anything and just read. She walks down a center aisle, the camera still in its parallel aisle, following her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless, of course, if-if you had some time, I mean, we could get some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't have time. Lee stops at the row where Elliot has been browsing.  She hidden by a shelf; only Elliot is seen as he talks to the offscreen Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  I-I-I understand completely. No problem.  Y-you're busy.  I-I-I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem tense.  Is everything all right?  You feel okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Elliot starts walking down the center aisle, in the same direction Lee had walked up.  He continues to talk to her she remains offscreen in a nearby row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offscreen momentarily, hidden by a shelf as he talks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offscreen momentarily, hidden by another shelf as he walks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How-how's Frederick? Elliot stops walking to browse through some books. "Bewitched" still plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  Oh, we went to the Caravaggio exhibition at the Met.  It's such a treat to go through a museum with Frederick.  I mean...you learn so much.  Do you like Caravaggio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to talk to the offscreen Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Elliot turns and walks back down the center aisle to a ro of books he'd already passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to a book on a shelf, continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e.e. cummings.  I'd like to get you this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I can't let you get me that. That's too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling the book off the shelf and browsing through it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, yes.  I-I-I-'d like to, uh, uh, very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing with the book, looking at the offscreen Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I read a poem of you and thought of his last week. (nervously laughing, trying to correct his mistake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his and thought of you last-- (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee walks over to Elliot in the center aisle.  She looks the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, uh, this is great.  I mean, I love e.e. cummings, but I can't let you get this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'd...I-I-I'd love, I'd love to get you this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And-and maybe, um...maybe we could discuss it sometime. He hands Lee the book.  She thumbs through it, as the mov cuts to: The street outside the bookstore.  Lee, holding the book a brown bag, and Elliot are walking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for showing me the bookstore. Perhaps you could, uh, take me to an AA meeting sometime.  Uh...uh, I'd love to see what goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, yeah.  You'd love it. It's really entertaining.  You'd have a good time. (stepping closer to the curb and hailing a cab)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, uh, d-don't forget the poem on page a hundred and twelve.  It reminded me of you. A taxi pulls over to the curb; they walk over to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  Well... Elliot opens the rear door for Lee.  She laughs as she ge in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning down to talk to Lee in the cab)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. He watches the taxi pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee, in slacks and shirt, is curled up on the bed, her ba to the camera, as she reads the e.e. cummings poem in the glow of a night-table lamp.  The piano music is still hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "your slightest look easily will unclose me though I have closed myself as fingers, you open always petal by petal myself... As Lee continues to read aloud, the movie cuts to Elliot' darkened den, lit by a light in the hallway.  Elliot ente wearing a robe, crossing the room in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...as Spring opens [touching skillfully, mysteriously] her first rose [i do not know what it is about you that closes and opens; only something in me understands the voice of your eyes is deeper than all roses]... Elliot turns on a light.  The camera stays on his face as looks off into the distance, mouthing indistinctly the li of poetry Lee next reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "nobody, not even the rain, has such small hands." The film leaves Elliot's face and cuts back to the loft, where Lee, having finished the poem, sits up in the bed, staring pensively, lost in her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The anxiety of the man in the booth. Upbeat jazz begins to play and the film cuts to: The faade of Mount Sinai Hospital.  It is day.  A few c whiz by as the film moves inside, to various scenes depic Mickey's comprehensive exam. First is a hearing test, and the movie cuts to a darkened hearing-test room.  A light goes on, revealing a slouched over Mickey sitting in a glass booth.  He is wearing a se of headphones.  The camera moves back, revealing a techni at the console on the other side of the booth.  Mickey signals with his finger when he hears a sound on his head The jazz continues. Next is an electronystagmography (ENG).  Graph paper roll out of a machine, and after a brief glimpse of the rollin paper, the camera moves over to show Mickey lying terrifi without his glasses, on a couch, with electrodes stuck al over his head. The film then cuts to a BSER test room, where Mickey, sitting in a corner chair, wears another set of headphone An electrode is attached to his forehead; a nearby techni sits at a computer video screen, looking at a monitoring graph. Last but not least is the tomography.  Over the shoulders a technician in a booth, a large window displays a huge, white rotating machine.  It makes a whooshing noise as it turns.  The camera moves down the giant cranelike device reveal Mickey, once again lying down, this time on a tabl his eyes closed, underneath it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sitting Dr. Grey, his back to the camera, is examining group of X-rays clipped to the light board behind his des

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't too happy with the results of your ENG or your BSER either. The doctor turns his chair around to face a tense Mickey sitting on the other side of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, which is why I sent you to Tomography, which was all that stuff you saw rolling around. (pointing to a spot on one of the X-rays)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this little gray area here? Mickey stares at the X-ray, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gray area's what I had hoped that we wouldn't run into.  I'd like you to come in Monday morning for, uh, a CAT scan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sachs, let's take one step at a time.  We won't make any decisions until we have all the information in front of us, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey is seen leaving the hospital.  He strides slowly, shoulders slouched, his hands in his pockets. His voice is heard over the screen as he crosses the stre continuing his self-absorbed walk on the opposite side. Occasional traffic goes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...take it easy.  He didn't say you had anything.  He just doesn't like the spot on your X-ray, that's all.  It doesn't mean you have anything.  Don't jump to conclusions. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
