dialogues.text: Nothing's gonna happen to you. You're in the middle of New York City.  This is your town.  You're surrounded by people and traffic and restaurants. Mickey brushes against a heavyset man who gives him a nas look.  Mickey is so dazed, he doesn't even notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, God, how can you, how can you just one day...vanish?  Keep calm.  You're gonna be okay.  Don't panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark bedroom is abruptly lit as Mickey, lying in his bed, wakes up with a start and turns on his night-table l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying!  I'm dying!  I know it! There's a spot on my lungs! (sitting up, putting on his glasses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right now, take it easy, will you?  It's not on your lungs.  It's on your ear.  No, it's the same thing, isn't it? (pulling the sheets off and sitting on the edge of his bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, jeez, I can't sleep!  Oh, God, there's a tumor in my head the size of a basketball! (putting on his slippers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N-now I keep thinking I can feel it every time I blink!  Oh, Jesus! He-he-he wants me to do a brain scan to confirm what he already suspects. Mickey, still ruminating, stands up.  Fixing his pants, h walks out of his bedroom loft into a dark upper hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look...I'll make a deal with God. Let it just be my ear, okay?  I'll go deaf.  I'll go deaf and blind in one eye maybe.  But I don't want a brain operation!  Once they go into my skull, I'll-I'll wind up like the guy with the, with the wool cap who delivers for the florist! He walks down a spiral staircase into the dark living roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, relax, will ya?  Your whole life you run to doctors.  The news is always fine. (pausing at the bottom of the stairs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true.  What about years ago? The film cuts to a flashback of Mickey's past.  Dr. Smith sitting behind his desk, faces the camera.  Rows of periodicals line the wall behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to say, Mr. Sachs, that you cannot have children. The camera moves to Dr. Smith's point of view: Hannah and Mickey, sitting on the opposite side of the desk.  They l stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting, putting his hands across his chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, naturally, this doesn't mean that you can't have a normal sex life. (walking over to the opened office door and closing it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mr. Sachs's tests indicate that he is infertile.  Small sperm volume and infertile. The camera moves back to the stunned Mickey and Hannah, following Dr. Smith with their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, looking up at an offscreen Dr. Smith)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there anything I can do? Push-ups or hormones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta get a second opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then a third opinion. Dr. Smith walks back to his high-backed leather chair beh the desk and sits down.  As he talks, the camera moves closer and closer to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize this is a blow.  My experience is that many very fine marriages become unstable and are destroyed by an inability to deal with this sort of problem.  I hope you won't make too much of it.  One can adopt children, and there are various artificial methods of fertilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey and Hannah walk on the sidewalk, oblivious of the passing pedestrians.  Hannah, crying, blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so humiliated.  I don't know what to say.  I mean--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, wiping her eyes with her tissue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you have ruined yourself somehow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I ruin myself?  What do you mean, ruin myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you gonna start knocking my hobbies?  Jesus! Hannah sobs, clutching her tissue to her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe we can adopt a child. He said you could adopt one--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, where I-I-I would get implanted from a-a donor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, by a st-stranger? Deep in conversation, they cross a tree-lined street.  Th pass a yellow wood-frame house bordered by a wrought-iron fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they have these banks, you know, where they keep them frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fro--?  You want a-a defrosted kid? Is that your idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a, with a stranger?  With a--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think about it.  That's all I ask. They walk offscreen and the film cuts to Hannah and Micke living room.  The room is brightly lit; it's cluttered wi pillows and plants.  Norman and Carol, his wife, sit on t couch drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was a wonderful show.  I think that's the best show you two ever wrote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the funniest show that Mickey and I ever did was the one we won the Emmy for. Mickey walks from the kitchen into the living room, holdi a half-eaten chocolate cake on a serving plate.  The sun pours through the windows he passes.  Hannah is briefly s in the background, preparing more coffee in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...I-I think as, I think as far as laughs, I mean just plain laughs, you know, that was probably the best thing that we ever did. Mickey puts the cake down on the coffee table, which is already crowded with assorted plants, plates, and a bambo tray holding utensils and napkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping, her hands over her crossed knees and nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was funny, it was very funny.  But the show was about the two Frenchmen, now that was funny and it was warm. Mickey sighs and flops down on an adjoining couch.  He ru his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got that idea on that trip to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember that summer in France?  Hannah, you had jet lag for six straight weeks. Norman chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it was, you know, I guess we had fun when we were there and, you know, it's just, I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. Hannah walks over to the group, holding a pot of coffee. She awkwardly steps past Mickey to pour coffee for Norman and Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee?  Listen, you guys, we were-- You want some more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We-we...we had something we-we really wanted to discuss with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Hannah refills Carol's cup.  She puts the pot down on the coffee table and sits down next to Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, this is, this is, this is very delicate and-and I only bring this up amongst friends, you know. He starts to pace.  Hannah, her hands clasped near her fa glances briefly at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to the group as he paces behind the couch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: this is, uh... this should not go any further than this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all ears. Hannah sighs.  Mickey pauses for a moment, collecting his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah and I...can't have any children.  Now I-I-I don't want to get into whose fault it-- (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault that we can't and- and-and the details are too embarrassing to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-w-we-we've decided after a lot of discussion that we-we'd try with artificial insemination. Mickey stops his pacing and looks at the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm not so sure that I, that I like that idea myself, anyway-- He starts to pace behind the couch anew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I-I didn't really want to, you know, go to a sperm bank or something, have some anonymous donor. (gesturing at Norman and Carol)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I just, you know, I-I-I wouldn't want that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  We felt that if we were gonna do it, that we would like somebody who we knew and who we liked and who was warm and bright and... Norman and Carol remain silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can say no... you know. Feel free to say no.  W-we realize it has all kinds of implications. Mickey stops pacing and leans on the couch behind Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the-the point that, uh, that we're making here is that we need some sperm. Mickey, rubbing his hands on his knees, leans back agains the wall.  Norman and Carol turn to each other, reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... My first reaction after the initial shock is, uh, flattered that you would ask me. (chuckling nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I would be the father. (pointing to Norman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would just have to masturbate into a little cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scooting closer to Carol and Norman on the couch, gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously we wou-wouldn't have intercourse. She chuckles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta tell you the truth here. I'm a little uneasy about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol, I know it's a lot to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I feel for you.  I do. I...I'm gonna cry.  You want my husband to have a child with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ye-- D-d-d-don't answer now.  Just, you know, take it home and think about it for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave blood before and, uh... clothing to the poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Norman, listen, I really want to talk about this at home. (nodding as Hannah looks briefly offscreen at Mickey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's a matter for your analyst...and mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And maybe my lawyer. He takes a sip of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, we-we understand completely if, you know, if you feel you'd-you'd rather not. (chuckling nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to spoil the evening. (rubbing her hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's move on to another topic. Hannah reaches for the cake as Carol and Norman exchange glances, reacting. The flashback ends.  Mickey is back in the present in his darkened living room, illuminated by a glow from a window behind the couch.  A coffee table sits in front of the co Papers are scattered on the floor.  Mickey gets up from t couch where he'd been sitting.  He paces back and forth a he talks over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you had my ex-partner's baby. Twins.  Maybe that did cause some trouble, but (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we were drifting apart anyhow.  Now instead of man and wife we're just good friends.  Boy, love is really unpredictable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manon Lescaut is being performed.  Onstage, the soprano i the title role sings a mournful aria as she kneels by the ruins of a wagon.  The background is dark.  The film move up to the private boxes in the upper loge.  David and Hol can be seen from a distance sitting in one of the boxes. David glances at her; he reaches down for a bottle of win The movie briefly cuts back to the stage.  The soprano is leaning on a wagon wheel; her voice soars.  Then it's bac to a closer look at Holly and David in their box.  The ar continues as David hands a smiling Holly a glass.  He uncorks the wine and pours some in both their glasses. Holly mouths a thank you, glancing around.  They look at each other and raise their glasses in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty bought this huge house in Southampton. The opera audience is heard cheering, applauding, and sounding their "Bravos." The clapping stops as the movie cuts to Frederick's loft. It is day.  Lee, wearing a baggy plaid shirt and jeans, h opened the door for Elliot and his client, wealthy rock s Dusty Frye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leading the way into the loft, gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee, Frederick...say hello to Dusty Frye. Lee closes the door behind the men and walks over to Dust

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Lee chuckles as she looks at him; he is wearing sunglasse a red-imprinted T-shirt, and a baggy coat.  She turns and walks with Frederick, Elliot, and Dusty farther into the loft, her hands clasped behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusty's just bought a huge house in Southampton and he's in the process of decorating it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  It's kind of a weird place, actually.  A lotta wall space. (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. They walk into the living room area of the loft, where Frederick, his hands in his pockets, neatly attired in ve sweater and white shirt, stands, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him about your work, and he's very excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got an Andy Warhol.  And I got a Frank Stella, too.  Oh, it's very beautiful. (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big, weird...you know. (chuckling as he crosses his arms on his chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you stare at that Stella too long, the colors just seem to float. It's kinda weird. Frederick covers his face to hide his disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you excited about becoming a collector?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a lot more to learn, though. I really wasn't into art when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (chuckling as he notices and points to some offscreen drawings Frederick has set up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  Hey!  Wow! (pointing to an offscreen nude drawing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's beautiful.  But, uh, really, I-I-I-I need something... I'm looking for something big. As Dusty talks, the camera follows Elliot, who walks past the others to examine the drawings more closely.  Two fra nude drawings of Lee are propped up on an easel.  Elliot glances admiringly at the drawings, then surreptitiously Lee, admiring her body as she converses with an offscreen Dusty and Frederick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big.  Frederick, show him the oils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the basement. The camera leaves Elliot to follow the enthusiastic Lee a she takes Dusty by the arm and starts leading him to the door.  Frederick follows at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederick's done this whole new series that I'm sure you would really love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Some of them...yeah, some of them are very big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I got a lot of wall space there. (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't sell my work by the yard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Frederick! The camera now moves back to Elliot, still staring at the nude drawings, as the sounds of Frederick's and Dusty's footsteps are heard leaving the loft.  He turns and hesitantly smiles to an offscreen Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know...I talked to Hannah this morning on the phone, and she said that you two might be going to the country for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she loves to go out in the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, her arms clasped around her chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I go nuts.  It's a conflict. He laughs.  Lee, uneasy, looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get my teeth cleaned this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice. There's an awkward moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking the silence, pointing in the direction of the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured I'd get, uh, Frederick and Dusty together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, that's really nice of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  This kid, he's earned a trillion dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, wrapping her arms around her chest again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got like six gold records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, relieved that she's found something to say)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, speaking of records...I bought that Mozart Trio you recommended... The camera follows Lee as she walks quickly to the stereo unit, pulling a record off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the man in the record shop showed me another one that I think you'd love.  It's a... another Bach, second movement. She pulls the record out of its jacket and puts it on the turntable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working at the stereo, turning her head towards Elliot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I would love to hear it. Bach's Concerto for Harpsichord fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and Holly met a wonderful man who loves opera.  An architect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice.  I'd love to see her wind up settled.  She's a tense one. (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The record in place, Lee turns and leans back against the stereo unit.  She listens to the music, her eyes closed. The record plays for a few moments in the quiet room, as Elliot walks over to Lee and leans against the shelf near

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Lee, his hands clasped in front of him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this.  Bach.  F Minor Concerto.  It's one of my favorites. Lee, smiling, continues to listen to the music, her head down; Elliot stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...did you ever get around to e.e. cummings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrapping her arms around her chest and looking away from Elliot for a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he's just adorable. Elliot nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have a very large gay clientele, you know, where I get my teeth cleaned, and...all the hygienists now wear gloves because they're afraid of AIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. There is another moment of silence.  Elliot stares at Lee who continues to look down, her arms around her chest.  T harpsichord plays on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever get around to the poem on page a hundred and twelve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it made me cry (tentatively looking at Elliot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it was so beautiful...so romantic. Lee looks down again; the music plays softly and Elliot continues to stare at her, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want so badly to kiss her.  Not here, you idiot.  You've got to get her alone someplace. As Elliot's thoughts are heard over the scene, Lee glance around the loft, then begins to walk away.  The camera follows her as she goes past the nude drawings, which bec the focus of attention as Lee walks offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've got to proceed cautiously. This is a very delicate situation. Okay, uh...ask her if you can see her for lunch or a drink tomorrow. Lee walks back onscreen, to the bookshelf behind the draw She takes the e.e. cummings book from the shelf and flips through it as she walks back to Elliot, who is still lean by the stereo, still ruminating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And be ready to make light of the offer if she's unresponsive.  This has to be done very skillfully, very diplomatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing Elliot a poem in her book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever read this one--? Elliot leaps up, grabs Lee, and kisses her passionately. Lee, surprised, pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee!  Lee!  Lee, I'm in love with you. He kisses Lee again.  He clumsily turns around; she humps against the stereo unit.  As Lee pulls away, she smashes into the turntable.  The needle scratches loudly.  Lee, shocked, is gasping.  The record, pushed to a different p of the concerto, now plays a more complicated, faster fug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I'm-I'm-I'm-I'm sorry.  I have to talk to you for... There's so much that I want to tell you. Lee stares at Elliot in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been in love with you for so long. Frederick and Dusty's indistinct voices, raised in argume are suddenly heard.  Elliot quickly turns away from Lee. She tries to compose herself and the film cuts to the lof entranceway.  Frederick enters the loft first, followed b confused Dusty.  They stride across the loft past Lee, wh is standing by the stereo.  Elliot, standing near the nud drawings, is looking through a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please forget it!  I don't have any interest in selling anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask you if you have something with a little puce in it, you gotta fly off the handle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling the nude drawings off his easel angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in what your interior decorator would think, okay?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't commit to anything without consulting her first. That's what I have her for, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is degrading!  You don't buy paintings to blend in with the sofa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a sofa, it's an ottoman! (touching his forehead, turning to Elliot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, forget it!  Let's just get outta here, Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go. The film moves outside the loft building.  Dusty and Elli emerge and walk to Dusty's waiting limousine.  Elliot is rubbing his forehead, anguished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a weirdo that guy is!  Paranoid. (noticing Elliot's anguished face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look I-I-I'll be okay.  I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that big a deal.  We just didn't hit it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look, you-you-you go on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?  You look-- You're sweatin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Yeah, I just-just need so- some-some fresh air.  It's probably something I ate.  I'll-I'll walk. You go ahead. Dusty settles down in the backseat and closes the door. Elliot leans down to the chauffeur's window, signaling fo him to start driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go.  Go on.  Go. The limousine drives off.  Elliot runs to a phone booth across the street.  He picks up the phone and dials. The film cuts to Frederick in his loft, standing near the phone.  It rings.  Frederick picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Hello?  Hello? When no one answers, Frederick, reacting, hangs up, and t film moves back outside to the phone booth, where Elliot, the phone receiver to his ear, listens for a moment, then hangs up.  He walks out of the booth, reacting, then walk down the sidewalk, where he bumps into a frantic Lee, jus turning the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  There you are! Elliot mumbles, relieved and confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, I must apologize.  I-I'm, I-I'm sorry.  I'm so mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how do you expect me to react to such a thing? Elliot, uneasy, glances up in the direction of Frederick' loft.  He leads Lee a few yards up the street, away from prying eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wh--, uh, I know, I know but, I am in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I, I'm sorry.  I know it's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing back her hair, shaking her head hopelessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you know the situation. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect me to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah and I are in the last stages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wh-- She's never said anything, and we're very close.  She'd tell me such a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wh--, it-it-it-it, it's so sad. She's crazy about me, but somewhere on the, along the line, I've fallen out of love with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not because of me, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I can't be the cause of anything between you and Hannah.  I jus--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, no.  It, uh, it-it-it- it was i-inevitable that Hannah and I part, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch, w-well, for a million reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch, no!  We were, we were both going in different directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But-but, but how about you?  Do you, do you share any of my feelings? Or is this just an unpleasant embarrassment to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-well, please be candid.  I, I-I don't want you to feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  But I...I have certain feelings for you, but don't make me say anything more, all right? Lee looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O-o-o-okay, Lee.  Okay, okay.  You, you, y-you've said enough.  It's my responsibility now.  I will work things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, don't do anything on my behalf. (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live with Frederick, and Hannah and I are close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but you, you do care about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Elliot, please!  I can't be a party to this!  I'm suddenly wracked with guilt just standing her talking to you on the street! She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your guilt is because you feel the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please, I have to go.  I have to get my teeth cleaned. She walks off.  Elliot stares after her, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my answer.  I have my answer! I'm walking on air! He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING
dialogues.text: A taxi turns a West Side street corner and stops in front Evan and Norma's building, which is decorated with a long metal awning.  It's an overcast day. A station wagon on the opposite side of the street pulls away as Hannah, a white scarf fluttering over her shoulde gets out of the cab.  She runs into the building; the tax drives away.  A piano plays "Bewitched" over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evan, his back to the camera, walks to the front door and opens it to Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am glad to see you. Hannah takes off her shoulder bag and her coat as her aggravated father walks past her towards the kitchen.  He passes a wall with an ornate mirror and some framed photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in the kitchen there.  It's the same thing.  Same thing.  She promises, promises. (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's all lies. Through a doorway, Norma can be seen sitting on a chair i the kitchen.  She wears a robe over a slip and stockings; she's drinking.  Evan stands in the doorway looking at he he doesn't go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always. Hannah hurriedly passes her father and enters the kitchen her mother takes a sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom.  How you doing?  Here, let me get you some coffee.  That's enough of that. (taking away her mother's drink, to Evan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, as Norma turns her head and watches him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were making a commercial down at the mayor's office, and there was this young, good-looking salesman... Norma reacts, turning to her daughter.  Hannah, however, her back turned.  She is busy taking charge in the kitche as Evan speaks.  She takes some pills out of a cupboard a hands them to her mother with a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and your mother was throwing herself at him in a disgusting way, and when she found she was too old to seduce him, that he was just embarrassed by her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar!  Liar! The camera moves to Evan, who continues to tell his story ignoring his wife's outburst, as he walks away from the kitchen doorway into the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then at lunch she got drunker and drunker (shouting over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and finally she became Joan Collins! Evan walks over to the piano, where several framed family photographs sit in a line on its top.  He picks one up as Norma speaks offscreen in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my life I've had to put up with insults... The camera moves back to the kitchen as Norma talks.  She still glaring offscreen at the doorway where Evan stood moments before.  She holds the water glass and the pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...from this non-person, this, th- th-this haircut that passes for a man. (turning to look at the offscreen Hannah)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He could never support us.  It's a good thing we had a talented daughter! Evan is back in the doorway, listening to Norma, getting more and more angry.  As he makes a retort, he starts to walk back to the den and his piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only hope that she was mine. With you as her mother (gesturing, his voice getting louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her father could be anybody in Actors' Equity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's talented...so it's not likely she's yours! (taking a sip of water)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking over to the doorway to speak to Evan, who's already fuming in the den)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, could you just please stay in the other room and let me take care of her? Hannah goes back to Norma; she takes the glass of water a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know when she's going to fall off the wagon and humiliate everybody. Hannah, choosing to ignore Evan's remark, hands her mothe cup of coffee; she puts her mother's hands on the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, Mom.  Drink this. (leaning against a kitchen counter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you're awful.  You probably were flirting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  I like to joke around and have fun, and he gets angry because I get the attention.  He's gotten sourer as he's gotten older, and I've tried to stay young...at heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised to stay on the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sacrifices I've made because of that man. (inhaling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's ruined me with his ego, his philandering, his-- (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the one that's made every ingenue in stock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Th-th-they, they wanted me for a screen test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I, I knew that he'd get up there and he'd flounder around with his expensive haircuts and hairdos and clothes.  He's all show! (touching Hannah's arm again, then touching her chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now how can you act when there's nothing inside to come out?! Norma sips her coffee, softly sobbing.  Hannah, reacting, walks away from the counter and, capping the bottle of pills, puts them back in the cupboard.  Evan plays the pi offscreen.  The camera moves in on Hannah's face as she reflects, her voice heard over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was so beautiful at one time, and he was so dashing.  Both of them just full of promise and hopes that never materialized. The camera leaves Hannah's face as she continues to refle it moves to the den, to the row of family photos on the piano: one of a present-day Evan and Norma, others where both Norma and Evan are young, beautiful, hopeful.  The music plays on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the fights and the constant infidelities to prove themselves...and blaming each other. It's s-sad.  They loved the idea of having us kids, but raising us didn't interest them much.  But it's impossible to hold it against them.  They didn't know anything else. The film cuts back to the kitchen.  Norma stands up; Hann takes her coffee cup and sets it on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, of all of us in the family, you were the one blessed with the true gift. She puts her arm around Hannah's shoulder.  Mother and daughter walk out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding the hand her mother had placed on her shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh, my true gift is luck, Mom. Norma chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just had a lot of luck...from my first show, you know?  I've always thought Lee was the one destined for great things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's lovely, but she doesn't have your spark. (gesturing and chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows it.  She worships you. She wouldn't dare get up there on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Holly's not shy. They stop at the entrance to the den.  Evan can be seen playing the piano as they continue their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Holly's game for anything. Holly takes after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have been a great dope addict. Norma chortles.  Hannah laughs, touching her mother.  The walk over to Evan at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember this, Hannah? Evan plays a few bars of "You Are Too Beautiful" as mothe and daughter, their backs to the camera, listen.  Norma leans over the piano; Hannah looks off into the distance, deep in reflection.  The piano music continues in the background as the movie cuts to: Lee walking along a wharf by the waterfront.  The wind bl her hair; she hugs the e.e. cummings book to her chest. She, too, is deep in thought.  She stops at the edge of t wharf; the camera continues to move, to a group of wooden pilings nearby, lapped by the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piano piece ends and the film is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quiet continues as the film cuts to a close-up of a large, circular CAT-scan module in an antiseptic hospital room.  A slowly moving stretcher, bearing Mickey's strapp prone body, begins to enter the round opening of the modu As the camera pulls back from Mickey, his taped head unde the scan, two technicians can be seen through the window separating the scanner from the control room.  One of the sitting down, taps information into a computer while the other technician stands nearby, looking from Mickey to th computer screen. The movie then cuts briefly to the computer screen, showi an image of Mickey's skull.  Scan lines bleep over the sk The camera moves up from the screen to reveal Mickey once again, as seen through the window, silent and serious und the CAT-scan module. From Mickey's prone form, the film moves to the two technicians, as seen through the window in the scanner ro They examine the computer screen and talk indistinctly to each other.  One of the men, nodding, taps more informati into the computer. While they're studying the CAT-scan picture, the camera c to a back view of Mickey under the module.  There is a science-fiction feel to this scene, as if Mickey is lying the center of a huge, white, futuristic circle.  The stretcher, bearing Mickey, slowly moves out of the module

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Brooks, holding Mickey's X-rays, walks past a row of bookshelves to his light panel.  He props up the X-rays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid the news is not good. Dr. Brooks turns to an offscreen Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing, taking a pencil out of his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can show you exactly where the tumor is, and why we feel that surgery would be of no use. The film quickly cuts to a close-up of Mickey's face, reacting in total despair.  He closes his eyes; he covers his face with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over.  I'm face-to-face with eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...grown quite large without being detected... (trailing off indistinctly as Mickey continues his anguished ramblings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not later, but now.  I'm so frightened I can't move, speak, or breathe. As Mickey finishes his speech, the "real" Dr. Brooks is s walking into the office.  The previous scene had been a figment of Mickey's imagination, a nightmare fantasy only Holding Mickey's X-rays, the "real" Dr. Brooks walks past the same row of books to the light panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're just fine.  There's absolutely nothing here at all. And your tests are all fine. (switching on the light on the panel and propping up the X-rays)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must admit, I was concerned, given your symptoms. (turning to look at the offscreen Mickey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What caused this hearing loss in one ear, I guess we'll never really know for sure.  But whatever it was, it's certainly not anything serious at all. (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, Mickey is seen leaving the building, but this time he bounds down the steps, jumping for joy.  He runs swirling down the street, clapping his hands, happy with relief.  Upbeat, uptempo jazz plays in the background. Several cars pass as Mickey joyfully runs.  Suddenly he stops, his hand to his mouth, reflecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gail sits in a chair in front of a bookshelf.  A sofa, a coffee table holding periodicals, and an endtable with a lamp complete the tableau.  Gail's hands are clasped on h lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean you're quitting? Why?  The news is good!  You don't have canc--the thing. Mickey, standing behind his desk, his back to the camera, his coat still on, looks out at the Manhattan skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize what a thread we're all hanging by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey, you're off the hook.  You should be celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking around to the front of his desk, gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you understand how meaningless everything is?  Everything!  I'm talking about nnnn--our lives, the show...the whole world, it's meaningless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not dying now, but, but (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you know, when I ran out of the hospital, I, I was so thrilled because they told me I was going to be all right.  And I'm running down the street, and suddenly I stop, 'cause it hit me, all right, so, you know, I'm not going to go today. I'm okay.  I'm not going to go tomorrow. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But eventually, I'm going to be in that position. Gail gets up from her chair.  She walks past Mickey to a nearby cabinet.  She opens a drawer, rummaging around for something.  The camera follows her, leaving Mickey briefl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't realize it now, I know it all the time, but, but I managed to stick it in the back of my mind... As Mickey continues to talk offscreen, Gail closes the cabinet drawer and walks to a file cabinet behind Mickey' desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...because it-it's a very horrible thing to... think about! Gail opens the file cabinet and takes out a pack of gum. She slams it closed, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tell you something?  Can I tell you a secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding impatiently as she walks around the desk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week ago, I bought a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting on the arm of a chair near Mickey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went into a store, I bought a rifle.  I was gonna... You know, if they told me that I had a tumor, I was going to kill myself.  The only thing that mighta stopped me, might've, is my parents would be devastated.  I would, I woulda had to shoot them, also, first.  And then, I have an aunt and uncle, I would have... You know, it would have been a bloodbath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch, well, you know, eventually it, it is going to happen to all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but doesn't that ruin everything for you?  That makes everything... Gail sighs.  She pops a piece of gum into her mouth as Mickey continues to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you know it, it just takes the pleasure out of everything. (gesturing, pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you're gonna die, I'm gonna die, the audience is gonna die, the network's gonna-- The sponsor. Everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, and your hamster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, kid, I think you snapped your cap. Mickey sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you need a few weeks in Bermuda, or something.  Or go to a whorehouse!  No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head, his hand to his chest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stay on this show.  I gotta get some answers.  Otherwise (pausing and holding his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, I'm going to do something drastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entrance to the St. Regis Hotel, elegant and warmly l in the night.  Pedestrians pass.  Baroque harpsichord mus plays over the scene.  The camera moves up the hotel's faade, past its welcoming flags, to its ornate windows several floors up. As the harpsichord continues to play, the film moves insi to one of the hotel rooms.  Elliot, his back to the camer is opening the door to Lee. Elliot closes the door behind her as she enters.  They st very close to each other, framed by the door and a stark, subtly striped wallpapered wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking intensely at Lee, his hands in his pockets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting his hand on her shoulder, wanting to kiss her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand away, gesturing to the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no-no-no, I'm sure. They walk towards the camera, further into the room.  Ell puts his arm around Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing, meeting in a hotel room?  It's terrible, isn't it? The music stops.  The camera follows Lee as she walks towards the curtained windows, past a fireplace, a mirror some innocuous pictures, a delicate table holding a lamp, the foot of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I couldn't think where to invite you without taking risks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised myself I wouldn't let this happen till you were living alone.  I was so torn when you called. She parts a corner of the curtains, looking out the windo turning when Elliot speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've wanted to call you everyday since I first told you how I felt. He walks over to Lee by the curtained windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think badly of me. He takes Lee into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not an easy situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it isn't. They kiss, their figures almost silhouetted in the warm g of the room.  Elliot takes Lee's coat off without breakin the kiss.  They embrace.  They kiss each other lightly, t stronger, more passionately, their embrace much tighter. And it's later that night.  The harpsichord music begins play again as the camera moves over the bed covers to rev Lee, lying contentedly under the sheets, her hair fanned on the pillows, one arm near her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was just perfect.  You've ruined me for anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want anyone else ever to have you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so worried I wouldn't compare with Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. He enters the screen, sitting down on the edge of the bed next to Lee.  He holds a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really do have those thoughts, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, all the time. Elliot chuckles; they hold hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she must be a really passionate person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's, she's very warm, but, but it-it's me that wants to be giving to you.  I-I-I want to do things for you.  Hannah doesn't need me as much. (chuckling as Lee laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm being presumptuous.  Not that you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to take care of me... And I love when you do things to me. Elliot leans down to Lee; they begin to kiss passionately

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee walks along the sidewalk in the rain; she's bareheade The streets are dark.  A car drives by; a pedestrian pass holding an umbrella.  Lee passes a restaurant well lit inside by hanging lamps.  The baroque music continues as enters the loft, her head soaked.  She closes the door, touching her soaking hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late. Lee walks through the loft's living room area, unbelting coat, towards the bathroom.  She passes Frederick, who si at a table in the kitchen area, drinking a cup of coffee reading the paper.  A plate with a half-eaten sandwich si in front of him.  The music stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and I kept talking, and I didn't realize how late it had gotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed a very dull TV show about Auschwitz.  More gruesome film clips...and more puzzled intellectuals declaring their mystification over the systematic murder of millions. As he talks, Lee is seen turning on the bathroom light. takes off her coat, hanging it on a hook, then begins to her hair with a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning his head slightly in Lee's direction and gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason why they could never answer the question "How could it possibly happen?" is that it's the wrong question.  Given what people are, the question is (swallowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Why doesn't it happen more often?" Of course it does, in subtler forms. Frederick takes a bite of his sandwich and another sip of coffee as Lee walks out of the bathroom, tossing the towe down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving her fingers through her wet hair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a little headache from this weather. She takes a kettle and fills it with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been ages since I sat in front of the TV... just changing channels to find something. As Frederick continues his monologue, Lee is busy in the background: striking a wooden match and lighting a burner the stove for the kettle, taking a glass out of the cupbo walking into the bathroom for some pills, filling the gla with water in the kitchen sink, and taking her pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the whole culture...Nazis, deodorant salesman, wrestlers...beauty contests, the talk show... Can you imagine the level of a mind that watches wrestling? (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm?  But the worst are the fundamentalist preachers...third- rate con men, telling the poor suckers that watch them that they speak for Jesus...and to please send in money. (picking up his sandwich)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money, money, money!  If Jesus came back, and saw what's going on in his name, he'd never stop throwing up. He takes a bite of his sandwich and a sip of coffee.  Lee sets her glass on the kitchen counter and walks towards t bedroom area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, Frederick, could you please lighten up?!  I'm really not in the mood to hear a review of contemporary society again. She starts to take off her wet clothes by the bed.  Frede takes off his glasses.  He turns and looks at Lee in surp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you've been very nervous lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to complete an education I started on you five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your pupil. (sighing, her hands at her side)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting down on the edge of the bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you leave the nest, I just want you to be ready to face the real world. He pulls Lee down next to him on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederick, we're going to have to make some changes. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know what.  I'm suffocating!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning away, his hands clasped in front of him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  Are we going to have this conversation again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we're going to have this conversation again.  I...I have to leave.  I have to move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to use for money?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I thought, maybe I'd move in with my parents for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch, oh.  I always told you you would leave me. (looking at Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...does it have to be now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hugging her arm with her other hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe it'll only be temporary, but I ha--I have to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking Lee's head in his hands and looking at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...Lee, you are my whole world. (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God!  Have you been kissed tonight?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting, pushing Frederick's hands from her face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop accusing me! Lee runs into the kitchen, her hands tight around her che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too smart, Lee!  You can't fool me!  You're turning all red! Lee, fraught with emotion, briefly puts her outstretched hands on the refrigerator door, then turns around and lea against it, hugging herself, her blouse still unbuttoned, her hair still wet and bedraggled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! Frederick enters the kitchen area and leans against the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ!  What's wrong with you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, couldn't you say something? You have to slither around behind my back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Frederick cringes, reacting.  He puts his hand to his forehead; he sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you, God, you knew that was going to happen sooner or later.  I can't live like this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to face Lee in the bathroom, his arms crossed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantically putting things in her purse, glaring at Frederick)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference?!  It's just somebody I met!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who?  Where did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make a difference!  I have to move out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are, you are my only connection to the world! Lee turns and faces Frederick in the bathroom doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, that's too much responsibility for me.  It's not fair!  I want a less complicated life, Frederick.  I want a husband, maybe even a child before it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, I don't even know what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch, oh, what do you get out of me, anyway?  I mean... (laying her head against his shoulder, sighing deeply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it's not sexual anymore.  It's certainly not intellectual.  I mean, you're so superior to me in every way that-- Frederick furiously shakes Lee away.  He pounds his fist against a cupboard.  Lee, gasping, moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't patronize me! He puts his hand on his forehead, then turns to the offsc Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God!  I should have married you years ago when you wanted to!  I should have agreed. He walks over to Lee in another area of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, don't you know it never would have worked? Frederick turns away from Lee.  He begins to pace near th counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, one day you would leave me... (leaning on the counter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for a younger man.  I-- He loudly pounds his fist on the counter in despair and frustration, then covers his eyes with his hands in sorro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, wearing a plaid shirt, sits up in bed, a book propped up on her knees.  A cupboard with some bric-a-bra is mounted behind the night table, which holds a small, white, warm-glowing lamp and some photographs.  She turns the page as Elliot, in pajamas and silk bathrobe, enters. She continues to read her book as he sits down at the edg of the bed and muses.  His voice is heard over the screen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What passion today with Lee.  She's a volcano.  It was a totally fulfilling experience... Just as I dreamed it would be. (nodding slightly as he takes off his slippers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it was.  It was like living out a dream...a great dream. (taking off his bathrobe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I feel very good and cozy being here next to Hannah.  There's something very lovely and real about Hannah. (tossing his bathrobe aside and lying down on the bed next to Hannah, his hands crossed over his stomach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives me a very deep feeling of being part of something.  She's a wonderful woman...and I betrayed her.  She came into my empty life and changed it...and I paid her back by banging her sister in a hotel room.  God, I'm despicable. What a cruel and shallow thing to do. (sitting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to call her now and tell her what we did was crazy. (anxiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't ever happen again.  I'm not that kind of man...and I value Hannah too much.  I love my wife. Now I've betrayed her.  Oh, God! Elliot frantically stands up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've, uh...gotta find, gotta get a phone number in my desk.  I forgot to phone Mel Kaufman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.  I-I can't believe I forgot. Elliot walks quickly into the darkened hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he answers? (turning into the doorway leading to the living room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hang up. (walking into the darkened living room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell her we can't communicate until I terminate my marriage. (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's immoral. Elliot switches on the light.  He paces back and forth in front of the piano and an accompanying music stand.  The of the piano is filled with family photos; the lamp he turned on illuminates some framed pictures on the wall an the piece of sheet music open on the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, time will pass.  I won't call, and she'll get the idea.  I gotta stop this before I get in too deep.  I'd rather hurt Lee a little, than destroy Hannah. Elliot stops pacing and checks his wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one-thirty.  She...she can't have a conversation with me...with him around.  I'm getting hysterical. (putting his hands on his hips)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call her first thing in the morning.  I'll call her at six. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frederick goes jogging at six, yeah, she'll be alone.  And I'll, I'll call her and nip it in the bud. The phone rings.  Elliot jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got it!  I've got it!  I've got it! (picking up the phone, into the telephone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (loudly, for the offscreen Hannah's benefit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel! The movie cuts to Lee, standing in the dark in Frederick' loft.  She talks softly into the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have hung up if you hadn't answered and I promise I won't ever do this again, but I just had to tell you, I feel very close to you tonight.  Very, very close. (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. Lee hangs up the phone and the movie cuts back to Elliot, standing in his living room.  Stunned, he slowly lowers t phone receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The only absolute knowledge attainable by man is that li is meaningless." - Tolstoy Jazz is heard as the movie cuts to the outside of a university library, the camera focused on a huge replica Rodin's Thinker before moving to the front entrance.  Mic can be seen emerging from its depths.  He wears his rainc his hands are in his pockets.  He ponders the scene as he walks past the statue and a small front garden and down t sidewalk.  Passersby, some holding books, are seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Millions of books written on every conceivable subject by all these great minds, and, and in the end, none of 'em knows anything more about the big questions of life than I do.  Ss--I read Socrates. You know, n-n-n--, this guy used to kn-knock off little Greek boys. What the hell's he got to teach me? And, and Nietzsche with his, with his Theory of Eternal Recurrence. He said that the life we live, we're gonna live over and over again the exact same way for eternity.  Great.  That means I, uh, I'll have to sit through the Ice Capades again.  Tch.  It's not worth it. The movie next cuts to a sunny day in Central Park.  A ma jogger, seen through some tree branches, runs by.  The camera moves past him, revealing a pondering Mickey walki by the reservoir.  He continues to talk over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, and Freud, another great pessimist.  Jeez, I was in analysis for years.  Nothing happened.  My poor analyst got so frustrated. The guy finally put in a salad bar. Several joggers pass Mickey; he continues to ruminate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  Look at all these people jogging...trying to stave off the inevitable decay of the body.  Boy (smacking his lips)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it's so sad what people go through with their-their stationary bike and their exercise and their... (glancing at a fat woman jogger in a red sweatsuit who runs by)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Oh!  Look at this one!  Poor thing.  My God, she has to tote all that fat around.  Maybe the poets are right.  Maybe love is the only answer. Mickey goes over to the chain-link fence encircling the reservoir.  He stops walking and looks out over the water

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh--Of course, I was in love with Hannah.  That didn't work out too well. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I even took her sister out. Remember that? Mickey continues to look through the fence at the water a the distant skyline.  A jogger crosses in front of him. It's very quiet; the soft jazz continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember years ago when Hannah and I got divorced and she fixed me up with her sister Holly? The film cuts abruptly to Mickey's flashback of his date with Holly, beginning with a rock club performance.  The soft jazz becomes loud, pulsating rock.  Three punkers--a girl with pink hair, a girl with a spiked mohawk, and a g with Stevie Wonder braids and sunglasses--watch and bop their heads to the sounds of the offscreen rock band, The Steps. The camera moves to the stage, revealing a sleazy-looking rock band in the midst of their number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I want to be like you I said I'm going to fit into your group..." As the band loudly plays on, the camera moves across the spellbound audience, sitting at crowded, smoky, small tables, to reveal a stricken Mickey and a mesmerized Holl squeezed together at one of them.  A nearby member of the audience swills beer from a bottle.  Holly, beating time the music and enjoying herself, takes a puff of her cigar She wears a wristful of silver bracelets.  She glances at Mickey impatiently.  He's the only one in the place weari a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I don't wanna be different Said I'm gonna be just like you Because I'm gonna buy the records That they play on radio... Holly turns back to the band, who are still in full swing The camera moves down the body of the lead singer, singin into a microphone, from his longish, curly red hair, thro his cut-off red shirt and sweaty torso, to his guitar.  H wears several silver bracelets on his wrists and gold bracelets on his upper arm.  The microphone screeches feedback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm gonna dance at clubs Gonna do just what I'm told Because I'm bleedin' now And I'm bleedin' now I wanna slip, slip, slip, slip, slip Into the crowd I wanna slip, slip, slip, slip, slip Into the crowd..." The camera moves back to Holly and the even more stricken looking Mickey.  They are crowded in with people.  In the background, a waitress holds up a tray.  A man drinks fro glass mug; people chatter indistinctly over the loud band The club is noisy, smoky, and thick with people.  Holly glances at Mickey once again, this time unable to contain her annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, why are you making those faces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear you.  I can't hear anything.  I'm, I'm, I'm, I'm gonna lose hearing in my ear!  I'm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, I, my ears are experiencing a meltdown!  I can't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, can't you feel the energy? It's tangible energy!  The room's alive with positive vibrations! She opens a vial of cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, trying to talk over the band)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly, I'm frightened!  I'm--After they sing... they're gonna take hostages!  Now let's-- Holly holds a short metal straw of cocaine to her nose an sniffs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't, no, please.  Will you-- No, don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing in the background while Holly and Mickey talk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I want to dress like you Say, I'll buy all the clothes I want to fuck like you Yeah, I'm sure it shows Because I'm..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, no, you've been doing that all night!  You're gonna...you're gonna burn a hole in your... You're gonna develop a third nostril!  Really, (putting his hand on Holly's shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: don't, please. While Mickey pleads with her, Holly puts her cocaine vial into her purse.  She holds a finger against one nostril a sniffs.  She then picks up her lit cigarette and continue to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the offscreen hand, bopping her head to the music and smoking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My--uh... The camera leaves the crowded tables and moves back to th band.  The lead singers continues to sing with his band, swaying his body to the music...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Gonna buy the records That they play on the radio..." ...as the film cuts abruptly to outside the rock club.  T music has stopped.  Mickey and Holly, almost in dark silhouette, are walking at a fast clip along the sidewalk arguing.  They pass some lighted clothing store windows; few cars go by in the dark street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love songs about extraterrestrial life, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not when they're sung by extraterrestrials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I cannot communicate with you!  I, you know, I never realized you were such a tightass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't understand you.  Your sisters, both sisters have such good taste in music.  I don't know where you went, went wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?  I'm-I'm my own person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take you someplace to hear something nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now come on, you're be--, 'cause you're being angry at me. They stop briefly at a street corner and look for oncomin cars before crossing.  Mickey takes Holly's arm as they w across the street towards the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not angry!  You know, you, well, you don't believe in ESP, you don't like rock music, you won't get high... It's like I'm dating Cardinal Cooke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Short is playing "I'm In Love Again" on the piano, accompanied by a bass player.  An Art Deco mural fills th wall behind him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Why am I Just as reckless as a child? Why am I Like a racehorse running wild? Why am I In a state of ecstasy? The reason is 'cause something's Happened to me I'm in love again And the spring is comin'..." ...as the camera leaves the musicians and moves to the conversatively dressed audience.  A far cry from the rock club atmosphere, the Carlyle is quiet except for Bobby Short's singing.  The audience at their tables watch him, some with smiles of pleasure.  A man has his arm around a woman.  Jewels sparkle in another woman's hair.  The men wear suits. Mickey and Holly sit at one of the tables; a candle burns its holder on the tabletop.  Holly takes a cigarette from her purse as she holds her hand to her nose, sniffing. Mickey keeps shooting glances at Holly; she can't sit sti Bobby Short continues to sing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm in love again Hear my heart strings strummin' I'm in love again And the hymn they're hummin' Is those cuddle-up huddle-up blues I'm in love again And I can't rise above it..." ...as Holly lights her cigarette, dropping her matchbook the floor.  She bends down to pick it up, then starts to fidget in her chair.  She gulps her wine; she sniffs. Mickey tries to watch the offscreen Bobby Short; he cross his arms across his chest. The film cuts back briefly to Bobby Short playing the pia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm in love again And I love, love, love it." ...then abruptly cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls away from the curb as Mickey and Holly walk of the hotel through its revolving doors.  Holly stays un the awning; Mickey walks to the curb and looks angrily ba at her.  People pass by as Mickey walks back and forth fr the curb to Holly, growing angrier and angrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you didn't like it, you didn't like it, but you didn't have to talk while the guy was singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's tough!  You don't deserve Cole Porter.  You should stay with those groups that look like they're gonna stab their mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I'm open to new concepts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't have to snort cocaine at the table all the time!  What do you, what do you do?  Carry a kilo around in your purse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This crowd wouldn't know the difference!  They're embalmed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... (waving his arm and whistling for a taxi)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad Hannah got us together. You know, she's got a great instinct for people.  Really. A taxi pulls up to the curb.  Mickey and Holly walk up to its rear door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look, I'm sorry it didn't work out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's probably my fault. I've been a little depressed lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I had a great time tonight, really.  It was like the Nuremberg Trials. He holds the door open for Holly.  She gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'll see myself home! Holly slams the door.  Mickey starts to walk along the sidewalk as the taxi drives off; he passes the hotel and several evening-lit store windows. "I'm In Love Again" begins to play in the background as Mickey's voice is hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was quite an evening. Holly with her cocaine... (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She should have been wearing a gold shovel around her neck.  Tch, she was polymorphously insensitive, I think. (smacking his lips)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad, too... 'cause, you know, I always had a little crush on her. Both a bus and a taxi drive down the street, blocking Mic from view.  The music stops and the film cuts to: Afternoons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big-band rendition of "You Made Me Love You" begins as film cuts to a hotel room.  Elliot and Lee can be seen dancing cheek to cheek in the reflection of a mirror over dresser.  A TV sits in the corner.  A lamp is on one side the dresser; on the other side is a bucket with champagne Two half-full glasses sit nearby.  Elliot and Lee dance i view.  Without missing a beat, Elliot picks up one of the glasses of champagne and hands it to Lee.  She sips.  Ell sips, then puts it back down on the dresser.  They embrac tightly, continuing to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elliot, Hannah, and the twins sit at the dining room tabl A Christmas tree stands in the corner of the room, next t table holding a lamp; a picture hangs on the wall.  The family has just finished eating; the table is cluttered w the remains of dinner, including a quart of milk, some chocolate syrup, and a bottle of ketchup.  Hannah's two adopted children stand by her chair; she is showing them a small camera works.  The children watch her, fascinated muttering among themselves.  Elliot looks listless.  He stares blankly at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to her adopted children, holding the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you just have to read the instructions.  I mean, you just set one of these things and you can take, you can take pictures underwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure!  Yeah.  When we get to the country, we'll try it in the lake. The child takes the camera from Hannah, as well as pickin up a second identical one from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!  Okay. The adopted children leave, the twins going off with them When they're gone, Hannah takes a sip of her coffee and looks at Elliot.  She puts down her cup, still watching h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in a bad mood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Um...I'm just antsy. The camera moves in on their faces as they continue to sp Family photos line the mantel behind Hannah's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I know.  The last few weeks, you haven't been yourself.  And tonight at, tonight at dinner, you, you were kind of curt with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you were.  A-and when I, when I brought up the idea of having a baby, you just, you jumped down my throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I-I don't think it's a very good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's the last thing in the world we need right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?  Is there something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell me.  Should I be worried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I-I think we should wait till things settle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what do, what do you-- (stuttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: what's that mean?  W-w-we've been, we've been married for four years. How settled can things get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, y-you have some very set plans on how your life should be structured.  A-a house, uh, kids, certain schools, a h--, a home in Connecticut.  I-it's all very...preconceived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I...uh--I thought you needed that.  When-when-when we met, you said your life was chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I-I know, but there's got to be some give and take. Hannah sighs.  Elliot angrily throws his napkin on the ta He stands up and begins to pace behind Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let's not--I, I don't know what the hell I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel, um...are you disenchanted with our marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in love with someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God!  Wha-what is this?  The Gestapo?  No. He sits down again, in a chair next to Hannah; the ketchu bottle sits in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what?  What, wh-what are you not telling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of interrogation... Su- supposing I said yes?  I-I-I am disenchanted.  I am in love with someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at Hannah for a beat before answering her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you keep asking these, these awful questions.  My God, it's-it's like you want me to say yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you, of c-- What are you talking about?  Of course not.  I'd be destroyed! The camera moves in on Elliot's anguished face.  He talks over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Chrissakes, stop torturing her. Tell her you want out and get it over with.  You're in love with her sister.  You didn't do it on purpose.  Be honest.  It's always the best way. He looks down.  Hannah leans over and tenderly puts her h on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, can I help you?  If you're suffering over something, will you share it with me? She touches his hand; Elliot embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, you know how much I love you. (kissing her on the forehead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to have my head examined. I don't deserve you. Elliot kisses Hannah again; they embrace tightly.  She touches his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen shows a metal staircase next to a large white column.  Holly's voice can be heard as she and Hannah mak their way up the stairs, moving into view.  A man carryin shopping bag walks down the steps; he passes them.  Hanna and Holly talk as they climb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I just want to look so good, but I don't want to seem, you know, like I'm overdressed. (onscreen, walking up the stairs behind Hannah)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up a dress she's carrying on her arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I, I really like that.  I think that's a pretty color on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah and Holly reach the top of the stairs.  They walk onto a cavernous, high-tech floor.  Empty bleachers line wall; the rest of the floor is filled with racks of cloth and empty space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
