dialogues.text: Did you ever think you'd be helping me buy something to wear to the opera? (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuh-uh...but I think it's great.  I can't wait to meet him. Holly follows Hannah to a rack of blouses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and his wife's, uh, in and out of institutions.  She's schizophrenic. Holly continues to talk as she follows Hannah across the floor to a rack of dresses.  Hannah's on one side, flippi through the hangers.  Holly, on the other side of the sam rack, talks to her sister, not looking at the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he has this sweet daughter...and when she goes to college next year, he's going to split permanently.  I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he's really paid his dues, but...then she helped put him through architecture school, you know, so... Hannah takes a jacket on a hanger off the rack and looks it.  She holds it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, glancing at her sister for a moment with amazement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found all this, all this out on one date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think he was dying to open up.  It's so sad. (finally looking back and forth along the rack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now...what should I wear to my audition? Hannah turns to Holly with surprise.  She puts the jacket back on the rack and stares at her; she inhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a singing audition for a Broadway musical. (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I'll never get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking around the rack to Holly, still surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I mean, why not?  You know, wh-what have I got to lose?  Uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no...I-I know, I just, uh... No, I-I, eh, you know, I, I didn't, I didn't know you sung. Hannah begins to look at the rack of clothes on Holly's side, while her sister stares at her, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you think everybody in m- musicals sings so well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  No, I, eh, it's just that they sing. Holly is silent for a moment.  Hannah takes a blouse off rack and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...you know, uh...I sing a little, I mean... (chuckling self-consciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hanging the blouse back on the rack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, y-you know, don't say it that way, you know, because my confidence is not my strong point,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry.  No, I didn't mean that.  No, I didn't mean that. The two sisters walk away from the rack, Hannah slightly the lead.  Behind them are some more racks of clothing an large window with closed venetian blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, you know, I think I can fake my way through a song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding as she looks around the store, pulling up her shoulder bag strap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easily. Holly pauses, looking at her sister.  They continue to wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-why?  You don't think it's realistic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't, I, that's no.  No, I- I-I, no, I-I just... (gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hate to see you put yourself in a position where, where you get hurt, you know.  You know, you know how you take...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They walk over to a table laid out with colorful scarves decorated with hurricane lamps bordering its edges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing, looking at some clothes hanging beneath the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...every, eh, single rejection as- as-as a...a confirmation that you have no talent, or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Well, maybe I'll get it. (chuckling and gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope. Holly looks at her sister for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you really know how to cut me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  You don't, don't be so sensitive.  Can't I say anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Chrissake, Hannah, you heard me sing! A female customer, who'd come over to the table, browsing through the rack of clothes near Hannah, looks up, reacti She walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I-- What happened?  You know, we were having a really nice time, a-and suddenly, everything went to bad feeling. She walks past Holly and briefly looks at a different rac of clothes beneath the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody but you can do that to me. I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, everything's going your way. She walks offscreen to a nearby rack; the camera remains focused on Holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy. (shrugging, looking at the offscreen Hannah)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why must I let my insecurities spoil everything? Holly chuckles and begins to look through the scarves on table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of theater executives, including the producer, th director, and two assistants, sit in a cluster in the emp audience, talking; they look up at the offscreen Holly, w is auditioning on the stage.  She is singing "I'm Old- Fashioned," accompanied by a piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "This year's fancies Are passing fancies..." The film moves from the audience to the stage where Holly her hands clasped in front of her, continues to sing her song.  A large group of other hopefuls are seen in the background behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing her singing, barely moving her body)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "But sighing sighs Holding hands This my heart Understands I'm old-fashioned And I don't mind it It's how I want to be As long as you agree To stay old-fashioned with me." The camera moves from Holly back to the executives in the audience.  As it passes the empty audience seats, they ar heard offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific. The camera has reached the executives in the audience.  T are now chattering among themselves, Holly forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April Knox? The film cuts back to the stage, where April, handling th audition pianist some sheet music, prepares herself to si "The Way You Look Tonight." The stage is very black, star except for April and the pianist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Someday When I'm awfully low When the world is cold I will get a glow Just thinking of you And the way you look Tonight..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A theater marquee can be seen on the busy street as Holly and April walk down the street towards the camera, moving closer and closer as they talk.  Workmen and various stre noises can be heard indistinctly in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, you sounded great. You, uh, you may be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm just glad we have a catering job this week.  I'm real low on money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we have Mr. Morris Levine's eightieth birthday party on Riverside Drive...or Riverside Memorial Chapel, depending on his health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, listen, David called me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, David called me last night, and he wants to take me to the opera. (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he called late last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to take me to see Rigoletto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I-I-I didn't know what to say. First I said no, but then, he pressed it.  He said, uh, he'd taken you once and he really wanted to invite me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I said that, but... (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he said it was something he really felt like doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's just an evening at the opera.  Did I, I-I do wrong in accepting? Holly looks away sadly; she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film cuts to Father Flynn's rectory office.  The Cath priest looks out a simple stained-glass window, then turn to an offscreen Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why do you think that you would like to convert to Catholicism? The camera moves back to reveal Mickey, his back to the camera, sitting in front of Father Flynn's desk.  A lamp lit in the background; the Father's desk is neat.  The ro is comfortably decorated in wood and leather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, because, y-you know, I gotta have something to believe in, otherwise life is just meaningless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  But why did you make the decision to choose the Catholic faith? The movie cuts to Mickey's face.  He's very neat in a tie sweater, and sports jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tch.  Well, y-you know...first of all, because it's a very beautiful religion.  It's very well structured. Now I'm talking now, incidentally, about the-the, uh, against-school- prayer, pro-abortion, anti-nuclear wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So at the moment you don't believe in God. The camera cuts back to Father Flynn, who walks over to a leather armchair next to a table set for tea.  He begins pour the tea into china cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  A-a-and I-I want to.  You know, I'm-I'm willing to do anything. I'll, you know, I'll dye Easter eggs if it works. (walking over to Father Flynn and sitting down in an adjacent chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I need some evidence.  I gotta have some proof.  Uh, you know, i- i-if I can't believe in God (gesturing, his raincoat in his lap)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: then I don't think life is worth living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means making a very big leap. Father Flynn clasps his hands in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, can-can you help me? The film abruptly cuts to the long hallway in Mickey's parents' apartment. In the foreground, a section of the living room can be se with a bureau holding a lamp and a framed photo.  The hallway itself is crowded with pictures and a wall shelf. At the other end of the hallway, in the background, is another bureau, with candlesticks on top and a framed picture on the wall above.  Mickey's mother stands in the front of this bureau at the hallway's end, screaming at t top of her lungs, holding her heart dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Oh, my God! She sobs hysterically, staggering offscreen to the bathro she shuts the door.  Mickey walks into view, in the livin room, looking after his shocked mother, who continues to over the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. (turning to his offscreen father)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that you would be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we be happy? His father walks into view, carrying a teacup and a candy dish.  He strides past Mickey towards the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, because I never thought of God in my life.  Now I'm giving it serious thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Catholicism?  Why not your own people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing at the kitchen door to his offscreen father)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I got off to a wrong foot with my own thing, you know.  B-b- b-but I need a dramatic change in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna believe in Jesus Christ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it sounds funny, but I'm gonna try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?  We raised you as a Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, just 'cause I was born that way... You know, I'm old enough to make a mature decision. Mickey's father walks into view; he stands by the stove n the kitchen doorway, picking up a dirty glass and some bo to clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why Jesus Christ?  Why, for instance, shouldn't you become a Buddhist? Holding the dirty dishes in his hand, Mickey's father loo at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Bud--?  That's totally alien to me.  Look, you're getting on in years, right?  Aren't you afraid of dying? Mickey's father walks offscreen again, to the kitchen sin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That thought doesn't terrify you? Mickey's father walks out of the kitchen, past his son, t the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who thinks about such nonsense? Now I'm alive.  When I'm dead, I'll be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.  Aren't you frightened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.  But never to exist again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it certainly doesn't look promising. Mickey stops at the bathroom door at the other end of the hallway.  He starts to pound it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows what'll be? Mickey's father comes back on screen; he's carrying a pla of hors d'oeuvres and an empty glass towards the kitchen. He stops and looks down the hall at Mickey, who's now struggling to open the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll either be unconscious or I won't.  If not, I'll deal with it then.  I'm not gonna worry now about what's gonna be when I'm unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course there's a God, you idiot! You don't believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if there's a God, then wh-why is there so much evil in the world? (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What-- Just on a simplistic level. Why-why were there Nazis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him, Max. Mickey, reacting, hits his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do I know why there were Nazis?  I don't know how the can opener works. Mickey starts pounding the door again as the movie cuts t A beautiful snow-covered church downtown, complete with courtyard and wrought-iron fence.  A pedestrian walks by with an umbrella.  A church choir sings a soaring hymn ov the scene. The music continues as the film moves inside, where the choir is seen singing behind an altar glowing warm gold. fairly large congregation sits in darkened pews as the fi cuts to the back, where Mickey, his arms crossed, stands underneath some stained-glass windows, watching and liste to the inspiring music. The choir continues to sing as the movie cuts to Father Flynn in his office. He picks up some large, heavy books from a shelf near his window and he walks over to Mickey, who's standing near h desk, already holding several tomes.  Father Flynn puts t books on top of Mickey's pile; Mickey, flipping through t top one, awkwardly carries his bundle to the door. Next is seen a close-up of a painting of Jesus Christ on cross, complete with crown of thorns and holy expression. His eyes, especially designed to blink as the lights hit them, open and close repeatedly.  The hymn plays on, loud as the camera moves back, revealing Mickey, standing outs a barber shop window, looking at the Christ playing and shuffling from side to side to gets its eyes' 3-D effect. Smaller inspirational pictures border the bigger, blinkin Christ.  A barber pole with moving stripes stands nearby; passing traffic is reflected in the window. Mickey turns from the window, shrugging, and starts to wa down the street, past a fruit and vegetable store with op air-displayed flowers, past several briskly moving pedestrians. With the hymn still playing, the screen goes black briefl Mickey opens the door, the light from a hallway illuminat him.  He's just entered his apartment.  He closes the doo and walks through his dark foyer; he carries a brown bag. He switches on the light, and walking past his spiral staircase, past several framed pictures on the wall, he makes his way to his living room coffee table.  Mickey pu a crucifix out of the bag; he looks at it, then puts it o the table near a pile of books and some objets d'art.  He then takes out a copy of the New Testament, putting it on top of the crucifix.  Then out comes a framed picture of saint.  It too gets put on the growing pile.  But the bag not yet empty.  Next comes a large loaf of Wonder Bread a a large jar of Hellman's mayonnaise.  Mickey sets them on top of the saint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee is walking down the street, looking around her.  The sidewalk is fairly crowded with people; the sounds of traffic are heard.  She passes some office buildings, a store's large display window; she stops when she sees Han Her sister is waiting outside the Art Deco faade of a restaurant; she's looking in the opposite direction.  Lee taps Hannah on the shoulder; Hannah, surprised, turns and gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. The sisters laugh and embrace each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  She's auditioning for a television commercial.  She said she's gonna be a little late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?  How's she doing? She turns and walks towards the restaurant entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, you know Holly.  When she's depressed, she's manic.  I think it was a good idea that we invited her to lunch. They disappear inside.  The camera follows them, cutting the restaurant's interior at the same time the sisters wa in.  It's a chic, trendy place, with an Art Deco design a high ceilings.  A waiter in uniform stands near its glass and metal doors, holding a tray to his chest; a few peopl sit at the bar; a large plant in a vase sits in the foreground.  The sisters walk toward the coatcheck area, deep in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling off her scarf, still on the subject of Holly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you tell her it was your idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...'cause every time I try to be helpful, you know, sh-she gets so defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Hannah, she's-she's just embarrassed in front of you, that's all. Hannah walks offscreen, farther into the coatcheck room. She talks offscreen as Lee alone is seen, reacting and speaking as well.  In the background, a waiter crosses ov to the bar, then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe Elliot and I can't think of someone nice for you to go out with, you know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, her voice slightly higher-pitched as she takes off her coat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, how's everything?  You doing okay?  How's Frederick? (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-yeah. Hannah walks out of the coatcheck room without her coat; it's Lee's turn to disappear and check her things.  Now o Hannah can be seen onscreen as the sisters talk.  In the background, the waiter once again walks over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's fine.  He's-he's, I guess he's fine.  I don't know. (shaking her head, her arms crossed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been kinda moody lately, the last few months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I-I don't know what's wrong with him.  He's just...kind of distant and difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to talk to him about it.  He says everything's fine, but I don't know. Automatically, you know, I leap to the worst conclusions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what? As Hannah answers her sister, Holly can be seen entering restaurant and walking over to the coatcheck area, an unl cigarette in her mouth, her sunglasses still on her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I don't know, he's seeing someone else or something, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking back onscreen without her coat, reacting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no!  I mean, everyone thinks things like that. Hannah mumbles indistinctly as Holly walks over to her sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I just came from an audition...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's new? She takes off her gloves and scarf, stuffing them in her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said I was too offbeat looking, whatever the hell that means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what do they know? Holly gives her coat to the coatcheck person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But guess who was there auditioning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April? The hostess appears, peeking around the corner of the coatcheck area.  She signals for the three sisters to fol her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it. Holly takes off her sunglasses; her cigarette still dangl from her mouth.  Hannah murmurs her sympathy as the trio follows the hostess into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was very polite.  I maintained my poise. (taking out a match for her cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said hello. The sisters walk to their seats, at a round table in the middle of the room; the hostess puts down their menus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.  I never trusted April, you know.  She has eyes in the back of her head. They sit down.  The hostess leaves.  Other diners are see in the background; a waiter is taking the order of a coup sitting on a banquette; other waiters clear off a table. Diners walk in and out.  A low murmur of conversation, as well as the faint clatter of dishes, is heard.  The camer moves closer to the three sisters, circling the table as Holly speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, she and an architect are now a very definite item, which I still cannot believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, although it's put an end to the Stanislavski Catering Company. Which is why I have to speak to you. And... (gesturing to Hannah)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you're gonna get impatient, but...I have to borrow some more money. (putting her cigarette in her mouth and picking up the matches)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, her cigarette in one hand, her matches in the other)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what I decided to do is some writing.  Yeah, I think I've had it with acting.  You know, these meaningless auditions at cattle calls.  And I can't handle another rejection. (emotionally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's face it here.  I gotta, you know, latch on to something in my life.  You know--something with a future.  I'm not sixteen anymore. (lighting her cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got...an idea for a story. More than one.  And I just need a few months, you know, or, uh, a year even. As the camera slowly circles the table, Hannah is seen listening to Holly, her hand on her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've picked up a lot about dramatic structure from doing my scenes in acting class. Lee, her hand on her mouth, glances briefly at Hannah.  A Hannah replies to Holly, the camera focuses on Lee's face She bites her nails; she looks down, involved in her own thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that-that's good.  It just, uh...it just seems to me that-that six months or a year, if-if you spent it more productively...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offscreen, the camera still focused on Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-well, like what? Lee looks up, her hand still on her mouth, watching Hanna as the camera slowly moves off her to show Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know.  We'd uh, uh, um... Didn't Mom mention there was something...something at the Museum of Broadcasting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  She, didn't she say it was, um...she said it was in the publicity department.  That-that can lead to other things. The camera is back on Lee.  She looks around tensely, bar listening to the conversation.  She fidgets.  An empty ta sits in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I knew you'd be discouraging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not!  I'm not!  I'm trying to be helpful.  A person doesn't just say one day, "Okay, now-now I'm finished as an actress.  Now I'm a writer."  I mean--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you mean not at my age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head, unable to take much more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please!  We all came to have lunch, didn't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, right.  Forget it. (puffing on her cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to eat? Holly abruptly picks up her menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want a salad. (to Hannah)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think I'm a loser, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You treat me like a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never have any faith in my plans.  You always undercut my enthusiasm. She puffs intensely on her cigarette as the camera slowly circles to Hannah's face.  She is equally intense, lookin at both sisters as she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so!  No.  I think I've been very supportive.  I've...I try to give you honest, constructive advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm-I'm always happy to help you financially.  I think I've gone out of my way to-to introduce you to interesting single men.  There's nothing I would--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I could always tell what you thought of me by the type of men you fixed me up with! The camera, slowly circling the table, is back on Lee's f While her sisters argue emotionally on her right and left she is looking down, biting her lip.  She is outwardly still, but her face is registering her seething emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hannah, I know I'm mediocre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting angrily, looking as if she's about to cry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, will you stop attacking Hannah?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going through a really rough time right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you've been picking on her ever since she came in here. Now just leave her alone for a while!  I'm just suffocating. (sniffing back her tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning over to Lee, puzzled, reacting to her sister's tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, Lee? Why are you so sensitive all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. (onscreen, as the camera circles around the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.  Listen. (tapping Holly on her shoulder and gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write!  Let's just not talk about it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take...take a year.  Take six months.  Whatever you want.  Who knows?  Maybe you'll, maybe you'll be sitting with a good play. She opens her menu, then turns to Lee, reacting suddenly her sister, who is rubbing her forehead, looking terribly upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?  What's the matter with you? (offscreen again as the camera circles back to Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm-I'm okay.  Yeah, I-I-I, you know, I...I'm just, um, I got dizzy all of a sudden.  I'm-I'm...I have a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still rubbing her forehead, looking down at the menu)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we need to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piano plays "Bewitched" in the background as the film c to a large tree, covered with bright white blossoms.  The camera moves down the tree to reveal a well-kept, red-bri brownstone on a pleasant, sunny New York City street.  A wearing a summer suit walks by as the film moves inside t building, to Elliot's analyst's office.  The psychotherap sits in a comfortable armchair next to a curtained window In front of the window sits a table covered with artifact and a large lamp.  The analyst's fingers are touching, hi arms resting on the chair, as he listens to the offscreen Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I can't seem to take action. I'm-I'm like, uh, Hamlet unable to kill his uncle. The music stops as the camera moves across the room to reveal Elliot, sitting in a wooden chair.  He holds a lon thin cigarette; he wears a gold Rolex watch.  He face is yet seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want Lee, but I can't harm Hannah. And in no other area am I a procrastinator. Elliot raises his cigarette to take a drag.  The camera follows the cigarette up to his face.  Elliot looks thoughtful as the movie cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee, wearing jeans and carrying an armful of books, is running up a broad set of steps in the sunlight, greeting other students as she passes.  Elliot continues to talk o the scene...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile...Lee has no direction. She's taking courses at Columbia...but just randomly. ...as Lee stops on a portico and turns to greet Doug, a professor, who is running over to her, calling her name. They mouth hello, smiling, and begin to walk off together

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try not to call her, but then she calls me and then...I call and...we try to resist meeting, but...once in a while we meet.  Sometimes we argue because I can't break up my marriage.  Sometimes we wind up making love and...we both feel terrible. The film cuts back to Elliot in his analyst's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's my fault. Elliot takes a last drag on his cigarette.  The camera follows his hand as he crushes it out in a nearby ashtray

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For all my education, accomplishments, and so-called wisdom...I can't fathom my own heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hare Krishna music is heard over a sunlit view of the Manhattan skyline and the green trees of Central Park.  T camera moves down to reveal a large group of Hare Krishna dancing on the broad green lawn among other New Yorkers enjoying the day.  The leader, holding some pamphlets, stands by a chain-link fence, a few feet away from his group, talking to someone on the other side.  It's Mickey as the camera soon shows, wearing a short-sleeved shirt, paper tucked under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you interested in becoming a Hare Krishna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not saying that I want to join or anything, but...but I know you guys believe in reincarnation, you know, so it interests me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was born Jewish, you know, but, uh, but last winter I tried to become a Catholic and...it didn't work for me.  I-I studied and I tried and I gave it everything, but, you know, Catholicism for me was die now, pay later, you know. And I just couldn't get with it. And I, and I wanted to, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...yeah, naturally.  Aren't you? I-- L-let me ask you, reincarnation, does that mean my soul would pass to another human being, or would I come back as a moose or an aardvark or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing some Krishna literature over the fence to Mickey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...read it over, and think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking down at the material he's just received)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay.  Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.  Hare Krishna. Mickey walks off, the Hare Krishnas still dancing and singing on the other side of the fence.  He flips through the literature as he walks, then looks straight ahead, pondering.  His voice is heard over the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you kidding?  You're gonna be a Krishna?  You're gonna shave your head and put on robes and dance around at airports?  You'll look like Jerry Lewis.  Oh, God, I'm so depressed. Mickey puts his hand to his mouth as another title appear on a black screen. Autumn chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bach's Concerto for Harpsichord is heard as the film cuts the waterfront at dusk.  A bench faces some wharf pilings the water gently laps against them as Lee walks into view the wind blowing her hair.  She stands and faces the wate and the distant skyline across the bay.  The view is contemplative, beautiful in the dim light. Lee is alone; her hands are in her pockets.  Lee, thinkin is heard over the scene; the harpsichord music plays in t background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nights are really getting cooler.  Summer went so quickly. Soon it'll be fall. (walking to the beach and sitting down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My literature professor really likes me.  It was fun being out with him last night. (staring pensively at the water)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny.  I feel like I'm betraying Elliot...but that's ridiculous. Why shouldn't I see Doug?  Elliot's not free. (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go one step at a time.  Let's see what the next few months bring. The concerto stops and the movie cuts to Holly, leaning i an open phone booth near a subway entrance.  She wears a football jacket, jeans, and sneakers; she holds a manuscr in her arms.  It's a busy corner.  People rush past Holly towards the subway; others are walking up the station ste Holly smokes a cigarette as she talks on the phone to Han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah?  Hi.  Listen, um, you'll be happy to know that your money has not gone completely to waste... No, I have an actual first rough draft of something I wrote... Yeah.  Yeah. Yeah, well, I showed it to Lee, and she gave me some good pointers. And, um, listen, I'm pretty near where you live.  I wonder if I could just drop it off...and, you know, when you have time, some time, read it, an-and we'll talk when I come over at Thanksgiving. Okay?  All right.  Okay.  Oh, wait, wait. (turning her body, still on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.  Listen.  I think Lee met an interesting guy at Columbia... Yeah.  Yeah, well, he sounds really nice... (puffing on her cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Okay.  All right.  Well, we'll talk at Thanksgiving.  Bye-bye. Holly hangs up the phone and takes a drag on her cigarett She looks off in the distance, smiling, as the film cuts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Thanksgiving at Hannah's once again.  Guests are crowded together in the living room, surrounding the pian where Evan is sitting and flipping through some sheet mus Norma stands behind him, leaning against a book-laden wal The guests are chattering, enjoying themselves; a lamp gl on the corner of the piano.  A little boy sitting in a ch next to Evan is talking animatedly with a girl who is leaning over the arm of the sofa.  An adult guest talks t the little boy; another guest takes a sip of wine from a glass she'd placed on the bookshelf behind her as Evan tu and addresses the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, here...here's a song that Norma sang on that trip we made up to the show in Buffalo.  And, oh, was she beautiful that night! The guests laugh appreciatively.  A woman comes over to E and hands him some wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. (laughing and touching Evan's shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, honey. (putting his drink down on the piano)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, you were, dear.  Don't you remember that night? (gesturing and pushing back some sheet music that was starting to fall)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was so beautiful...she was so beautiful that when men saw her walking along the streets, they'd drive their cars right up on the sidewalk. He laughs; the guests laugh with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight exaggeration. The guest continue to laugh; they are charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But only slight. Evan continues to laugh with everyone as he starts to pla the piano.  A nearby woman toasts him with her drink.  Th camera moves around the room as he plays, showing the various guests, chattering over the music.  Some are in clusters, in private conversations; others listen and wat the offscreen Evan.  A couple stands by the window; one m gets up from his chair and walks away.  Some guests sip their drinks, smiling, as the camera moves back to the pi and the book-laden wall.  Evan is playing the piano with exuberance.  Norma, still standing behind him, has a poignant, wistful expression on her face.  She mouths the words to the song Evan is playing, "It Could Happen to Yo The woman next to her smiles, enjoying the music, as the camera continues its exploration, moving to a man standin in the doorway with a group of children.  Mavis the maid walks by with a tray of hors d'oeuvres.  The man takes on mouthing his thanks, as the camera travels past the open bookshelf, past two boys in suits who are drinking soda a munching, to reveal Lee.  She is leaning against another doorway, a faraway look on her face as she listens to the music.  Mavis passes in the hall beyond the doorway.  Sev people, deep in conversation, stand nearby as Elliot, holding a drink, walks up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been very cold to me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing back at Elliot, then turning away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are too many people around. Lee slips past Elliot and walks away.  Elliot looks back her briefly, then, sipping his drink, he turns and looks offscreen at the crowd in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly is standing in the pantry, preparing some offscreen food.  Near her is a restaurantlike swinging door with a glass porthole.  In the foreground, the kitchen table is crowded with bowls and plates of food.  An open cupboard separates Holly from the rest of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hannah?  You know, I think Lee is really serious about her new boyfriend.  Yeah, eh, from what I understand he sounds really nice. Hannah walks into view, headed for the refrigerator.  She carries two tomatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy for her.  I think she's in love. Hannah opens the refrigerator, totally ignoring Holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a bunch of celery out and slamming the refrigerator door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm real upset about what you wrote. Hannah walks over to the table, gathering up more food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obviously based on Elliot and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not "Oh, so loosely"!  Real specifically!  Is that how you see us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging, walking out of the pantry area)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I, can I not accept gestures and feelings from people?  Do I, do I put people off? Holly walks over to the sink and washes her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a made-up story. She dries her hands as Hannah, her arms laden with vegetables, strides over to her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's real exact!  The-the situations, the dialogue, everything. It's-it's full of intimate details between Elliot and me! Which I don't, I don't see how you could even possibly know about.  A conversation we once had about adoption? Hannah storms out a nearby door as Holly turns away from sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing, the towel still in her hand, as she speaks to her offscreen sister)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Lee mentioned that to me, so obviously you discussed it with her. You... (pacing around the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just took the essence and I blew it up into drama. Holly wipes her hand on the towel as Hannah reenters the kitchen, carrying even more vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see how Lee could know about these things.  I don't!  I don't tell her everything. Hannah strides into the pantry area and flops the vegetab down on the counter.  Holly puts the dishtowel down and absently straightens some things on the food-laden table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, I guess I hit a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make it sound like, you know, I have no needs or something.  You think I'm too self-sufficient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping her mindless straightening at the table, reacting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Hannah, that's not what I meant, you know. (walking offscreen to the sink area)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, everybody relies on you for so much. "You're so giving. It's not a criticism.  We love you. We're grateful."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking out of the pantry to the food- laden table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're grateful, but you resent me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wow!  I don't want to have this conversation.  I didn't do anything wrong. Hannah angrily gathers up some spices from the table; Hol walks back onscreen holding a silver ice bucket.  She sto at the corner of the table and faces Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-you mentioned to me yourself that you and Elliot were having some problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're having some problems, but problems that are my business...which I don't see how you could know about in such detail. How does Lee know about these things?  How?  They're private! Hannah picks up a large bowl and carries it, as well as h armload of spices, into the pantry area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to look at her sister as she walks past)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you share them with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't...I don't want to bother everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the point.  I'd like to be bothered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see how you could know about these things unless Elliot's been talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he hasn't.  If I offended you, I'm sorry. Hannah, reacting, puts the spices down on the pantry coun Holly turns away. The film cuts to the dining room doorway.  Guests can be seen mingling and talking and helping themselves at a buf table in the living room.  Lee and Elliot can be heard offscreen as the camera slowly moves from the doorway acr the empty dining room to reveal them in the midst of an intense conversation.  The piano, as well as soft chatter is heard in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, Elliot.  I don't know how to make it any clearer.  It's over.  I can't see you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm just as much at fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If-if-if you can believe I have such feelings for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to be honest with you.  I met someone else.  I've met someone else. (turning and walking away from Elliot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I told you I wasn't going to wait forever. Lee goes over to an open door and closes it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it hasn't been forever. (walking over to Lee at the just-closed door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been nearly a year since our first time and you're still married to my sister, which...I now realize is fine because you're probably much more in love with her than you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we-we made so many plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Uh, well, sure we did.  An- an-and in a way you led me on, because I truly believed you were unhappy with Hannah.  Otherwise, I would never have let myself be drawn in.  I was very weak.  So were you.  Now I've met someone else. The door opens and Mavis appears, holding a set of candlesticks.  She walks over to the dining room table, which is already decked out with a floral centerpiece, glassware, and china.  She puts them down as Lee and Elli stand awkwardly near the door, waiting for her to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  Good. Mavis leaves.  Both Lee and Elliot quickly close the door behind her and immediately pick up where they'd left off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care a great deal about him, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to put his arm around Lee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, it's over!  Elliot, I mean it. It's over! They look at each other, reacting, as the film cuts back Hannah's kitchen.  Norma's face can be seen in the portho window on the other side of the pantry's swinging door. looks around the kitchen, then opens the door and steps inside.  Holly stands nearby, working in the pantry area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding the door, half in and half out of the kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, I loved your script.  I thought it was so clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Norma, smiling, and holding a glass of wine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're my mother.  Not everybody's gonna be such a sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I particularly liked the character of the mother.  Just a boozy old flirt with a filthy mouth. Holly chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mom, thanks. Norma steps back out of the kitchen, the door swinging sh behind her.  Holly looks at the door, sipping her wine, a the movie cuts back to Hannah's living room.  A chubby, friendly uncle sits on a sofa, one child on his lap and several others gathered cross-legged around him on the fl They lean on the coffee table, which is covered with glas and a bowl of chips.  Other guests mingle in the backgrou one couple enters the living room, smiling at the scene o the sofa.  Mavis crosses the well-lit foyer in the backgr and opens the door to more guests.  The piano plays on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his bottle of beer to the children)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now here's a toast to Thanksgiving, all right? The children mutter their enthusiastic agreement, picking their "illicit" glasses of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we supposed to have beer? Yeeeah! The uncle pours more beer from his bottle into the kids' outstretched glasses.  They cry indistinctly with excitem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me at it! (to one of the little boys)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, Fletcher? Laughing, he turns to the little girl sitting on his lap; clinks his bottle against the bottle she is holding, whic is almost as big as she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doll?  To Thanksgiving.  Here's a little toast, doll. (clinking glasses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  Bottoms up. The uncle and the children happily drink their beer as th movie cuts to a wall with subtly patterned wallpaper in Hannah's bedroom.  Her face moves on to the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been talking to Holly or Lee about us?  About our-our personal life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's things Holly wrote about in her script about us that are so...personal they could only have come from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I've got a splitting headache and I don't like being accused. Hannah walks towards Elliot; he's in the bathroom standin over the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not accusing.  I'm asking.  Do you...do you find me too...too giving? (closing the door of the bathroom slightly so only she is seen on the screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too-too-too competent?  Too-too, I don't know, disgustingly perfect or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Elliot walks from behind the partially closed door to an offscreen medicine cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following Elliot and gesturing, talking to his back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what is it then?  What?  Eh, what's come between us?  How have I alienated you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a bottle of aspirin from the cabinet and walking back to the sink, gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never want to talk about it. I-- Every time I bring it up, you- you change the subject.  What is it? Do you-- We're communicating less and less.  You sleep with me less and less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily turning to Hannah and pointing as she shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, I am very mixed up!  Now please! Elliot turns back to the sink, once again obscured by the partially closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacting, her voice trembling slightly, and gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you talk to Holly or Lee behind my back?  Do you?  You must.  They- they seem to know so much about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking towards a towel rack and gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I've asked advice once or twice or-or made a joke. He dries his hands as Hannah, standing behind him, contin to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you do?  Do-do-do you talk to Holly, or Lee, or what?  Do you, do you, do you phone them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, can you?! He closes the door, briefly obscuring Hannah and himself from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I've told you.  I need someone I can matter to. The camera moves behind the closed door, into the bathroo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to be around someone who gives so much and-and needs so little in return! He opens the medicine cabinet and puts the aspirin bottle back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, look...I-I have enormous needs. Elliot slams the medicine cabinet shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't see them, and neither can Lee or Holly! He leaves.  Hannah watches him go, reacting.  She is stun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark hallway is illuminated by light coming from the offscreen foyer; pictures line the wall.  Piano music is still heard very softly in the background as Hannah, hugg herself, walks slowly down the hallway into the living ro She briefly looks around, lost in thought.  She sits down heavily, tiredly, on the arm of the couch as the movie cu to several framed photographs on the mantel.  One shows Hannah and Elliot on their wedding day.  Another shows Elliot, obscured in the shadows.  Yet another has capture Norma as a young girl.  The camera, however, moves closer and closer to a photograph showing Hannah, Lee, and Holly the three sisters, smiling into the camera.  There is no sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film shows the bedroom night table, holding a small lamp, a wooden box, a cast-iron fire truck, an ashtray, a glasses.  Elliot's pajama-clad arm moves into view.  He turns off the lamp; the room is now pitch-black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so pitch-black tonight.  I feel lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not lost. Elliot turns the lamp back on, then turns to Hannah; she lying on her side of the bed, partially in shadow.  He le over and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you so much. They begin to kiss passionately as "Bewitched" starts to play in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bewitched" continues as the film cuts to a busy nighttim New York City street.  Mickey, his hands in his pockets, walks along the sidewalk, one person among many other pedestrians.  He pulls his coat tighter around him as he walks. "Bewitched" continues to play as he passes Tower Records' neon-lit window.  He glances inside...and sees Holly, her jacket flung over her shoulders, looking at so records. Mickey walks through the revolving doors of Tower Records up a few stairs to the selling floor proper, and stops ri in front of Holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, I don't know if you remember me, but we had the worst night of my life together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was walking past and I saw you in here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I thought I'd come in and...and we could replay, uh, the whole, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's putting it mildly.  We did everything but exchange gunshots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, really.  You do.  You do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember slamming the cab door in my face and.. (touching his nose as Holly laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you know, it came very dangerously close to emasculating my nose in a... (touching his nose again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, that was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look wonderful.  You do.  What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I hope you have, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so for your sake, because, uh, your personality left something to be desired...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and for yours.  I'm sure you've changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...namely a personality. Holly chuckles and turns to look at more records.  She wa down the aisle, occasionally glancing at the bins of reco Mickey walks beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't answer my question. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...just some stuff.  A little of this, a little of that, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Is that an embarrassing question?  Should I have not asked it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you, are you out of work or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, well...I've been trying to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up a record and looking at it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's interesting.  Wh-what kind of stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...well, you-you're not interested in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, millions of people come up to you and say, "Hey, I have something I just wrote," right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.  Yeah.  This is really--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting, turning from the record bins to look at Mickey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, wo-would you be willing to-to read it?  Something...that I wrote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I would if, uh, if it would mean anything to you.  I don't know why it would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the reason I ask is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've always hated my taste in the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't.  No, the reason why I ask is I think it might make a great, uh, television script, and, you know, you're so active in television, so--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not anymore.  I haven't, I haven't been in television for a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done no television whatsoever. No. As Mickey continues to speak, Holly walks to another bin records, reacting to his words.  She looks offscreen at h then down at some records.  The camera follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may, I may have to get back into it, 'cause my accountant says that I'm running out of dollars. But...but, um, no, I haven't, I just sort of dropped out for a year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...which is a long, dull story and I won't get into it.  But-- Mickey walks back onscreen to Holly.  The two of them are partially obscured by a large white Jazz sign imprinted w a large red circle as they continue their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm-- Yes.  Yes, I'm fine.  I'm fine.  How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...what about your script? (face offscreen obscured by the sign)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd love it if you'd read it, actually, 'cause I really would value your opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to remember, we-we-we didn't agree on one thing. They emerge from behind the Jazz sign, still walking, sti talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have to remember while you're reading and you're cursing my name, you know, that this is my first script.  Well, it's not my first script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, my first script was about Hannah and her husband, but, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hannah read it, she got really angry, and... you know, then I felt badly, so I-- She picks up a record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, God, I can imagine what you wrote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no!  It wasn't anything bad. But she just... you know.  I don't know. Mickey pulls out a record and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, uh...I threw it out, but I have this other one. Holly looks hopefully at Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, I-I-I...you know, if you want me to, I'll read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, could I come over tomorrow and read it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over tomorrow and read it to me? Holly laughs, embarrassed, as Mickey puts the record he's been looking at back in the bin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be joking.  I've been doing all my own reading since I was forty...you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.  I think it's lucky I ran into you. (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have kept going.  I-I have a sneaking feeling, a nagging sensation I should've kept walking and... Holly chuckles, looking off for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and not begun this conversation. There is a brief pause and the movie cuts to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen shows a chaise in Mickey's apartment; an ashtr on a stand sits nearby.  The camera moves down the chaise past several piles of books, to Mickey's coffee table.  H sits, picking at his fingers and listening, on the edge o the table in front of Holly, who is sitting cross-legged the floor, propped up with a pillow, reading her script a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offscreen, as the camera moves across the room towards her and Mickey, reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We all go through life playing the hand we're dealt.  Craig: And what hand were you dealt? (onscreen now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Emily: I'm two high pair, maybe even aces up.  The problem is, you've got three deuces." Holly closes the script and looks up at Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the end. Mickey smiles and shrugs, not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you can tell me straight.  It's okay.  Just, you know, tell me what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great.  I swea-- I'm-- I'm, tch, I'm speechless.  I was...I was not in the mood to listen to this thing now. (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.  I'm moved and I laughed and I-- Uh, I, you know, I was on the edge of my seat.  I just think it's wonderful! I'm, I'm totally...stunned.  This is not an insult.  I'm amazed that you can... (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was-- I just thought it was great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  I was abso-- And...w- what...made you think of that climax scene where the, where the... architect is walking home with his actress girlfriend and-and the ex- wife who's schizophrenic jumps out of the bushes and stabs him to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it just came to me one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was just fabulous!  I'm, I, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping, hitting her forehead with her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, gosh, you really think I can write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was wonder-- There's maybe one or two things in there that I would do differently myself, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabulous, I mean it!  I'm so impressed. Holly, thrilled with Mickey's overwhelming response, stan up, her hand on her head. Unable to contain herself, she begins to walk up and down the room, holding her script.  The camera follows her; Mickey is now offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  You-you made my day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just great.  Uh, I was all set...I was set to be bored stiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, gee.  Would you like to have lunch?  Uh, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I would love to talk to you about, uh, that script.  I-I, you know, I think maybe that we could do something with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, and listen, I would like to hear what made you suddenly decide to drop out of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-you used to-- Oh, no!  Yeah, I care.  You used to be so ambitious and... (pausing, grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you really liked it?! "You Made Me Love You" starts to play as the movie cuts t the street outside Mickey's apartment house, an old build complete with a red entrance door and a gray, weather-bea faade.  Trees line the sidewalk.  Holly and Mickey emer from the door and walk up the street, revealing a whole r of similar apartment buildings.  They pass a few other people as they walk. The film then moves to the outside of a charming glass an stainedwood caf.  Through the window, Holly and Mickey be seen having lunch.  Holly is talking animatedly; Micke takes a sip of coffee.  Some people pass by. Next, the film cuts to an almost isolated path in Central Park, complete, with old-fashioned streetlamps and scatte leaves.  Holly and Mickey stroll into view, deep in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, you really went through a crisis, you know that?  H-how did you get over it?  I mean, when I ran into you, you seemed, you seemed just perfectly fine.  Well, you seem fine now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day about a month ago... The film abruptly cuts to Mickey's flashback, a visual counterpoint to the story he is telling Holly.  A close-u of a nervous, perspiring, and panting Mickey alone in his apartment appears on the screen as his voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I really hit bottom.  You know, I just felt that in a Godless universe, I didn't want to go on living.  Now I happen to own this rifle... (coughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey raises the barrel of a rifle to his forehead.  He shuts his eyes tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...which I loaded, believe it or not, and pressed it to my forehead. And I remember thinking, at the time, I'm gonna kill myself.  Then I thought...what if I'm wrong? What if there is a God?  I mean, after all, nobody really knows that. The camera moves past the desperate Mickey to a mirror on the wall behind him.  Its reflection shows his spiral staircase and some standing lamps.  A clock faintly ticks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then I thought, no.  You know, maybe is not good enough.  I want certainty or nothing.  And I remember very clearly the clock was ticking, and I was sitting there frozen, with the gun to my head, debating whether to shoot. The gun goes off with a loud bang.  The mirror shatters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of a sudden, the gun went off. Mickey, holding the rifle, is seen running over to the shattered mirror.  The sounds of his excited neighbors, their shouting, a knocking door, are heard as he continue his tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had been so tense, my finger had squeezed the trigger inadvertently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but I was perspiring so much, the gun had slid off my forehead and missed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I heard a gun.  Is everything all right? Mickey, still brandishing the rifle, runs into his sunlit living room.  He looks around frantically, his shirt loos Finally, he throws the rifle down between the sofa and th coffee table.  The gun goes off a second time.  Mickey, standing nearby, jumps, his hands flying to his head.  Th doorbell rings; the neighbors begin pounding at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly, neighbors were, were, pounding on the door, and-and I don't know, the whole scene was just pandemonium.  And, uh, you know, and I-I-I-I-I ran to the door. Mickey runs offscreen briefly to answer the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I-I-I didn't know what to say. You know, I was, I was embarrassed and confused, and my-my-my mind was r-r-racing a mile a minute... He returns onscreen, panting; he looks frantically once again around the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I-I jus knew one thing. The film cuts to a West Side street.  It's an overcast da Mickey, walking slowly along the sidewalk, passes several other pedestrians and numerous storefronts, including Klein's Pharmacy and a "Bar-B-Q" take out.  Occasionally, is obscured by a tree trunk on the opposite side of the street; a few taxis go by as he talks over the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I-I-I-I had to get out of that house.  I had to just get out in the fresh air and-and clear my head. And I remember very clearly.  I walked the streets.  I walked and I walked.  I-I didn't know what was going through my mind.  It all seemed so violent and un-unreal to me.  And I wandered... The movie cuts to the exterior of the Metro movie theater with its smoked glass entrance doors and its Art Deco fee An old publicity photo hangs inside.  Mickey's reflection seen at the almost-transparent doors, as well as the reflection of the street and various cars whizzing by.  H reflection walks towards the theater entrance; he continu his story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...for a long time on the Upper West Side, you know, an-and it must have been hours!  You know, my, my feet hurt.  My head was, was pounding, and, and I had to sit down.  I went into a movie house. I-I didn't know what was playing or anything. Mickey walks into the movie house.  He is seen through th glass doors, which still reflect the street and traffic outside.  He makes his way through the lobby into the act theater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just, I just needed a moment to gather my thoughts and, and be logical, and, and put the world back into rational perspective. The film abruptly cuts to the theater's black-and-white screen, where the Marx Brothers, in Duck Soup, play the helmets of several soldiers standing in a line like a liv xylophone.  The sounds of the "xylophone" are heard as th movie cuts to the darkened theater, where Mickey slowly s down in a balcony seat.  The "xylophone" music stops and changes to "Hidee-hidee-hidee-hidee-hidee-hidee-ho" as su by the Marx Brothers and ensemble in the movie.  The sing continues faintly in the background as Mickey continues h tale:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I went upstairs to the balcony, and I sat down (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and, you know, the movie was a-a-a film that I'd seen many times in my life since I was a kid, an-and I always u-uh, loved it.  And, you know, I'm, I'm watching these people up on the screen, and I started getting hooked o-on the film, you know? The film cuts back to the black-and-white movie screen as Mickey continues to talk.  The Marx Brothers, as well as hundred-odd other cast members in Duck Soup, are kneeling and bowing as they sing "Hidee-hidee-ho." They kick their heels up in the air.  They sway back and forth, hands clasped, singing "Oh-h-h-h-h-h..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And I started to feel how can you even think of killing yourself? I mean, isn't it so stupid?  I mean, l-look at all the people up there on the screen.  You know, they're real funny, and, and what if the worst is true? The movie cuts back to Mickey, sitting almost obscured in the dark theater.  The Oh-h-h-h-h-h's coming from the offscreen movie are heard as he continues to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if there's no God, and you only go around once and that's it? Well, you know, don't you want to be part of the experience?  You know, what the hell, it-i-it's not all a drag.  And I'm thinking to myself, geez, I should stop ruining my life... As Mickey talks, the film cuts back to the antics of the Marx Brothers on the black-and-white theater screen.  The four brothers are now swaying and singing and strutting, their voices indistinct over Mickey's narration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...searching for answers I'm never gonna get, and just enjoy it while it lasts.  And...you know... The film is back on Mickey's dark form in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...after, who knows?  I mean, you know, maybe there is something. Nobody really knows.  I know, I know "maybe" is a very slim reed to hang your whole life on, but that's the best we have.  And...then, I started to sit back, and I actually began to enjoy myself. As Mickey continues, the film cuts back to Duck Soup on t black-and-white screen.  The Marx Brothers are sitting on judge's bench, playing banjos and singing with the other cast members.  They jump down from the bench, still singi Their voices swell. MARX BROTHERS & COMPANY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh, Freedonia Oh, don't you cry for me They'll be coming around the mountain..." The Marx Brothers kneel, strumming their banjos, and the movie cuts back to Central Park.  The flashback is over. Mickey and Holly continue their stroll as "You Made Me Lo You" begins to play in the background.  They pass some people, a cluster of buildings that look like castles, an the Manhattan skyline as seen through the trees, as the camera moves back, farther and farther away from them, showing a beautiful Central Park, frozen in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um...look, there's something I've, uh, that's been bothering me for a long time, and I just thought I'd just tell you what it was and just sort of clear the deck here, and (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I've always regretted the way I behaved that evening we went out, and, uh...I've, I just thought I'd tell you that because I really made a fool out of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be silly!  No!  Don't be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the, I was... You know, it was my fault.  I-- (inhaling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, so you want to go out to dinner again?  I mean, is that, is that... Have, you have any interest in that, or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?  I mean, are you, are you, are you, are you free this evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They stroll offscreen. "You Made Me Love You" grows loude and the film cuts to: One year later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, perfectly roasted turkey on a serving plate brie fills the screen as the camera moves across the food-lade table in Hannah's kitchen, past an electric mixer, severa bowls, spices, tomatoes, and parsley, to reveal Evan walk through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want ice!  Who's got some-- (pointing to an ice bucket on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on the table, Dad. The sounds of Thanksgiving guests in the other room are dimly heard; "You Made Me Love You" continues softly in t background.  Mavis passes the table, licking some food of her hand.  Hannah, in the background, is busy by the stov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where's Holly?  She's late. As Mavis leaves the kitchen, Lee enters, carrying some em glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Hannah, did you read that last thing Holly wrote?  It was great. She's really developed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offscreen, in another area of the kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, she...she really writes good dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I'll get some ice. Lee walks off, drying her wet hands in the air.  Hannah, a silk dress, moves onscreen, going to the table and pour herself a glass of wine as Norma enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hannah, can I tell everybody you're going to play Desdemona? Norma walks over to a glass-doored cabinet and takes out bottle of gin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a big sip of her wine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mom, it's only television. (beginning to mash some sweet potatoes in a bowl on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but it's public television. And to me, Shakespeare doesn't get any greater than Othello.  You with some big black stud!  I love it! Norma unscrews the liquor bottle and pours some into her empty glass as Hannah stops her mashing, reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey! The movie leaves the kitchen and cuts to the doorway betw the dining room and the living room.  Upbeat jazz plays o the low din of the party.  Two women stand by the partial set dining room table, chatting and arranging some plates as Elliot strolls into view, sipping a drink.  He passes women and walks through the doorway into the living room, nodding hello to a guest who is walking the other way. He enters the living room, smiling.  It is crowded with guests; Hannah's children play in their midst.  One of Hannah's boys grabs Elliot's arm.  They playfully "spar" a moment before Elliot laughingly shakes him off, continu on his way into a connecting room.  He stops at the doorw looking at the crowd.  The camera shows his point of view Guests stand in clusters, enjoying themselves; one woman chats with a little boy; another woman, carrying a drink, walks over to a group of other guests. The film then cuts back briefly to Elliot, holding his dr and looking straight ahead, as it shows his point of view once more.  This time he sees a smiling Lee and Doug, talking animatedly; a few guests are seen in the backgrou Elliot's voice is heard over a close-up of the couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lee, you are something. Lee and Doug kiss each other.  They continue talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look very beautiful.  Marriage agrees with you.  Everything that happened between us (pausing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: seems more and more hazy. As Lee takes a sip of her drink, the movie cuts back to Elliot, standing in the doorway and still staring straigh ahead.  The camera moves in closer to his face as he talk over the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I acted like such a fool.  I don't know what came over me.  That complete conviction that I couldn't live without you. The film quickly cuts to a brief look at Lee and Doug, st talking animatedly and smiling.  Lee gently pushes back Doug's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I put us both through? And Hannah... The camera moves back to Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who as you once said, I love much more than I realized. After pausing for a moment on Elliot's face, the film cut to the foyer, where two boys and a girl gather by the doo One boy opens it, revealing Holly.  She joyfully enters t apartment, greeting each child with an enthusiastic kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't miss dinner, did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! The jazz ends as the record scratches and stops.  Evan's rendition of "Isn't It Romantic" is heard on the piano as Holly, shrugging the strap of her pocketbook off her shoulder, walks towards the living room.  She is stopped three guests--two women, one of them wearing glasses, and man--who are coming out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you.  Same to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. The movie cuts to Hannah, leaning contentedly against a doorway into the living room and listening to the offscre Evan play the piano.  Elliot, holding his drink, walks ov to her.  They look at each other for a beat; Elliot then hugs Hannah, pulling her towards him.  She leans her head his shoulder, fingering his jacket lapel.  They look offscreen together, happily, intimately, at the offscreen guests, as the camera moves across the room, past a few guests, to reveal Evan sitting at the piano.  Norma sits his side, one arm resting on the piano.  She holds a drin and looks off in the distance, mouthing the words to "Isn It Romantic." The camera then moves to the doorway in the living room, where a man, holding a drink, enters and joins the happy crowd.  Evan can be seen in the background, playing his s A child plays near the coffee table. The camera continues to move past the doorway, past a hug grandfather clock, to a second doorway leading to the den Here, more guests are gathered; a child sits in a small chair by the sofa.  He sips a soda as female guest #2 ent the room and crouches down next to him, smiling.  She wav to him.  He waves back as the camera continues to move pa the doorway to reveal Holly, standing in front of a hallw mirror, fixing her earrings.  Mavis can be seen in the background, through the doorway into the dining room, lighting the candles on the table.  She dims the lights, darkening the room and the hallway where Holly stands in warm candlelit glow.  Mavis leaves the dining room and passes Holly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. Mavis walks off.  Holly, reflected in the mirror, begins fluffing her hair as Mickey enters and wraps his arms aro her from behind.  The camera stays focused on the mirror; both Holly and Mickey are now seen in its reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't get nervous.  It's just your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look so beautiful. Mickey continues to kiss Holly.  She responds, sighing an closing her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I was talking with your father before...and I was telling him that (kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: it's ironic.  I-I used to always have Thanksgiving with Hannah...and I never thought (kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: that I could love anybody else. (kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here it is, years later and I'm married to you (kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and completely in love with you. (kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heart is a very, very resilient little muscle. (kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd made a great story, I think. A guy marries one sister... (kissing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: married to the other sister.  It's, you know, it's a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you're gonna top that. Mickey continues to kiss Holly's neck; he chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant. The mirror shows Mickey pulling away slightly, reacting. They look at each other at arm's length, Holly grinning. Mickey in shock, then embrace and kiss passionately, tigh and tighter, as the music swells... And the credits appear, white on a black screen.
